Ottawa, February 7, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, upon the occasion of your visit last month.

In reply I have to say that an order will be placed here for three fire extinguishers to be used in the barns at the school. These will be forwarded, addressed to the Principal, and the account, in triplicate, will be sent to you. On receipt of the extinguishers, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and forward for payment.

The Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $25.00 in the purchase of the plank flooring required for the repairs in the horse stable. It is noted that you instructed the Principal to have the timing gears of the Lister lighting plant repaired. Please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the plank flooring and the repairs to the lighting plant.

If possible, all these accounts should reach the Department before our books close at the end of the present fiscal year, viz.: March 31st, next.

With reference to the request that a large pump be supplied, to be used in emptying the septic tank, I would ask that you inform the Department concerning the

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
type of pump recommended by the Principal and yourself and also the approximate cost. I would request, further, that you submit an estimate of the cost of erecting a small ware-house, with cement floor, to be used for the storing of flour. Our funds are extremely limited, and it will not be possible to authorize the supplying of the pump or the erection of the ware-house until the Department is advised definitely concerning the cost involved. When this information is received, consideration will be given as to whether funds can be provided.

Regarding any refills that may be required for the fire extinguishers, I would request that you arrange for the purchase, locally, of the chemicals necessary, if the refills are required at the present time. If you make the purchase, you should see that the Principal has the extinguishers overhauled and the refills installed and that all extinguishers on hand at the school are in good condition, ready for immediate use.

I am not aware as to the circular referred to by you regarding refills for fire extinguishers. The latest circular with reference to fire equipment and the prevention of fire hazard was addressed to Principals of schools, in February, 1932. A copy is enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, February 27, 1934.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, I beg to say that you may purchase for use at the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, one diaphragm pump for emptying the septic tank. It is noted that this can be secured at $39.00. You may also purchase 20 ft. of 3" hose which, it is noted, can be secured for $27.00.

Accounts covering the cost of the above should be forwarded as soon as possible, in order that they may be paid from this year's Appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzies,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter 121-5-5 of February 7th last, fifth paragraph, regarding cost of a four warehouse for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the Western Steel Products of Winnipeg quote a price of $85.00 on a 10' X 16' XXXX metal building, sales tax included, being a complete metal and lumber structure f.o.b. factory Winnipeg. This is the building desired by the principal.

There would be freight in addition to the above, also cement for flooring, lumber for lining the building, so it would cost at least $150.00.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

May 30, 1934.

Dear Sir,

I am today in receipt of a telegram from Indian Agent Waddy of Punnichy, Sask advising that the water supply system at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School is nearly shut off by quick sand, and that the Principal asks that a well-boring firm be employed to clear out the casing or do any necessary work required.

Before acceding to the Principal's request I would ask you to please arrange to have one of the Engineers of your Calgary office make an inspection and report at the earliest possible date.

I may say that this system was installed from plans prepared under the supervision of your Calgary office.

I am advising Indian Agent Waddy that you are being requested to investigate.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Ottawa.

Preliminary Report

on

WATER SITUATION

at

Muscowequan Indian School

Lestock, Sask.,

By

P.A. Betterly, B.Sc., R.P.E.

1. Purpose of Report.

Instructions were received from the Director, dated May 31, 1934, stating that the water supply system at the above named school is nearly shut off by quick sand and requesting that the matter be investigated. The writer made an inspection on June 16.

2. Requirements of the School

The number of inhabitants of the building consist of 110 pupils and 30 on the staff with families, a total of 140. There are also 20 horses, 110 head of cattle and 15 or 20 pigs. The total water for the people and stock has to come from this well as there are no lakes or suitable sloughs near. This occurs especially in winter, when the greatest danger exists. The total requirements, as a general average, amount to 6000 or 7000 gallons.

3. History of Water Supply

The original well (No.1) was excavated by hand to a depth of 40 feet and is cribbed with concrete pipe 3' diameter and 3' long. This well was excavated about 1910, when the original frame school was constructed on the same site now occupied by the new...
school (1930). It was apparently fed by practically surface water and now contains 2 feet of water and is entirely unused. The surface supply dried up as is the case with many Western wells.

Well No.2 was drilled in 1930. It is a 6" hole 5-5/8" casing 3" pipe, with a 3" cylinder. It is equipped with a Beatty pump. This pump has a tested capacity of 400 gal. per min. It really consists of parts of two pumps which were on hand as the school Engineer claims that the pumps did not "stand up."

The school Engineer states that rain water and leakage enters the pit rendering efficient work by the motor difficult. This pit cannot be heated. The pump was placed in a 10' pit so it would not freeze. However, it cannot be kept dry or warm.

Previous experience would tend to show that wells and pumps should be constructed contiguous to the buildings (but not in them) so that the basement containing them can be heated by direct connections.

4. Detailed History and Behaviour of Well No.2.

This well was drilled in 1930. Mr. Dempsey, the driller, working for McPherson & Thom of Regina, who is not now available for interviewing, drilled to 92 ft., found hard water, pumping 240 gal. per hr. This was not enough, besides being hard, so he drilled to 145 feet and found 420 gal. per hour. When he used the baler everything was all right, but when a pump with a
capacity of 600 gal. per hr. was used the well "plugged" with sand and "mud". Dempsey thought that if a smaller pump had been used, allowing the water to enter the casing more slowly, it might have been better as the mud would not have been drawn in by the pressure. However, this is only supposition. Dempsey then quit. The well "plugged" shortly afterwards so he tried again. He could not do anything so he drilled to 204 feet and then to 225 feet. He found it dry at 225 feet. He then pulled the casing to the 90-foot vein and filled the hole from 225 ft. to 90 ft. with gravel.

A 7 foot screen was placed at 142 feet but plugged so it was never replaced. It at present is stored in its original box in the implement shed. This was examined by the writer and it was found that the slits were enlarged by a hacksaw in an attempt to prevent plugging.

The casing now stands at the 91 foot vein, consequently the water at present obtained is possibly a mixture of the 142 ft. and 90 ft. water.

The 142 ft. water analysed 22 grains of hardness per gallon of water, making it good for general use.

While the writer was present the engineer pumped about 400 gallons in 3½ hours. This about 100 gallons per hour, corroborating his statements.
Behaviour

The well was not fully plugged on June 16 at the time of visit, although it produced only 100 gal. instead of 400 which is the least that the school should have, at present the water is shut off the toilets etc., in order to conserve water. A sample of the mixture of fine sand and silt, collected from the fixtures upstairs is being sent to you under separate cover.

The well pumped some mud near the beginning of its life. It was hardly ever clear for the first year. Then it cleared up in 1931. Then every six months or so it pumped a little mud. However, the supply was always more or less sufficient until May 1 when it went down to 100 gal. per hour. This lasted 3 or 4 days, pumping mud, then it cleared for a week and then pumped mud for 3 weeks. It has been opened up for 3 weeks now, without pumping mud. The school Engineer stated that the general yield at present is 250 to 300 gals. per hour. There has been no mud lately and the well is at present behaving fairly well.

It might be noted that at the time this well was drilled pumping was continued for 96 hours. It cleared up. No blame whatever can be attached to any one, including the representative engineer from this office (not the writer) for misbehaviour of the well. The mud is in the water and no engineer or driller can foretell what will happen or what is the nature of the material or the conditions appertaining at that depth. An examination of the sample will indicate the difficulty of excluding it by screen or
by any other method. It will also be noted by an examination of the log of the well, which is enclosed, that dynamite was used in an endeavour to enlarge the basin. It is the considered opinion of the writer, judged from previous experience, that trial and error must be used under these conditions.

The tank has been cleaned several times since 1930. It was found to contain a coating of "mud" 1/4" thick or so. No doubt the whole system throughout the building is coated as evidenced by the sample. One confesses that the alternate plugging and clearing of the well is a matter difficult to explain. If the mud appears, why does it not permanently plug the well? The gravel inserted from 225 ft. to 90 ft. may have some effect.

5. Recommendations.

At the immediate present the school can carry on with some difficulty and with a depleted supply, but if and when the well fails a serious condition obtains. This would be really serious in winter when the stock have to depend entirely on the well. The following data might be considered rather as opinions than as recommendations at the present stage.

In the case of Blue Quills Indian School several hundred dollars was spent in trying to rehabilitate the old well. It was at last improved about the time it was decided to abandon the attempt. This well now works well, at least semi-permanently.

Two possible methods are available in the
present case, as follows:

(a) Clean Well No.2.

If this be done the school would be without a source of supply while the experiment was being tried. This would be a serious condition as no other supply is available, although the tank could be filled. This contains only 1000 or 1200 gallons, portion of one day's requirements. This method could be tried however at a cost of $150 or more, depending on the distance a driller had to take his outfit.

Inquiries were made regarding available drilling outfits. Mr. S. Dempsey who drilled the well is at present running his own outfit. His home was, and probably still is, at Indian Head. A well-driller named Planchot (given name unknown) who lives at Punnichy, has a boring machine, and could probably obtain a drilling machine, if necessary. No other well-drillers could be found in this area.

(b) A new well No.3.

This should be constructed in the alcove contiguous to the power house and near the air compressor on the outside of the power house. This new well could be
entirely drilled as a 6" hole to the 142 foot vein or it could be bored and concrete-lined to, say 60 or 70 feet, to act as a reservoir and then drilled to the 142 foot vein. The bored portion would also act as a stilling basin to minimize the "pull" of the pump and prevent stirring up of the sand. The capacity of a 3 foot bored hole would be 70 ft. less 30 feet (the depth of water table) or about 1700 gallons.

It appears to the writer that, judging by the behaviour of the present well, that two wells are needed, providing a proposed additional well behaves as the present one. They could then be used alternately. As yet this can only be considered as a suggestion as one is diffident about advising the construction of another well under the circumstances. Regina, August 4, 1934.

Gentlemen,

Further to my letter of August 2 regarding the well at the Indian School at Lestock, I drove over there yesterday, to get all the information possible on this well.

I find that the 92 ft. water supply comes from a very shallow layer of sand and gravel, being only one foot in thickness, and then again at the 142 ft. level there is only 3 ft. of sand and gravel.

About the first paragraph in your letter said that you were asking to have this well cleaned out not a new well put in. I believe it is impossible to do anything with the present well and every dollar spent on it, is just that much wasted.

I will try to explain how I have come to this conclusion. In the first place both of these water bearing stratas are very shallow and would be, more or less, stirred up with mud, before the driller would realize he was in sand. Then the lower level at 142 ft. was pumped at 600 gallons per hour. It was more than the capacity of the well. This drew in a certain amount of sand and mud and allowed the overhanging layers of clay to mix with the sand part. The same thing applied at the 92 ft. level when the casing was pulled back to that point. I believe that the sand is practically all pumped away for a small area around the bottom of the casing and then every little
while some more clay from above drops down shutting off the water. This is what happened when the supply drops down to 100 gallons per hour. Then it gradually increases when this clay is washed away by the action of the water. Another thing that helps so spoil both these water layers is the fact that drilling was completed down to 225 feet. It is very seldom a good well is left after driving the casing down any great depth below the water supply as the couplings in the pipe both coming down and going back help to stir up the sand and mud together. Another thing should any work be started on the present well you would be entirely without a water supply while the work was under way and it is just possible after the bottom of this well was stirred up at all the water might be shut off completely.

When at Leestock yesterday, I looked up your agent there, Mr. Waddy, and explained very carefully to him why it was impossible to get any satisfaction from this well. I told him the only thing that could be done was a new well and I suggested two ways of finishing this -- either to use the 142 ft. water by itself, or to use a screen part way up the casing, and use both supplies, that is, at 92 ft. and 142 ft. He said they would much rather only use the water from the 142 ft level, as it is much better than what was secured higher up.

What I recommended to him yesterday was an 8 inch well, down to 142 ft. explaining that the 8 inch screen in the shallow layer of gravel and sand would give a much greater area for the inlet of the water than it would be possible with a smaller screen.

I am quite satisfied that what Mr. Dempsey said
was correct, that the well was plugged originally by being pumped too fast. The bailer test at this depth was apparently around 400 gallons per hour. And I am quite satisfied that with careful pumping this might have been increased, through time, but the fact that it was pumped at 600 gallons per hour, completely ruined it.

Even though you did not ask for a new well, I am taking the liberty to submit the following quotation for an 8 inch well as discussed with Mr. Waddy.

$6.50 per foot. This included casing, drilling and transportation, plus well screen at $100.00

This price may look high to you on the drilling end but transportation is a large item considering the amount of footage there will be in this well.

Another thing, an institution of the size you have at Lestock should never be left with only one water supply, as no one knows when the pumping equipment may be broken down. As long as the present well is left as it is, you would always have that to fall back on as a temporary supply, should anything go wrong with the equipment in the main well.

Should you decide that the 8 inch well is too big, and ask for an 6 inch instead, there would be a saving of approximately $150.00. I don't believe this small saving would warrant putting in the smaller well.

I have tried to cover this subject as fully as possible, but if anything has been overlooked, let me know and I will try and explain. I appreciate very much your offer of this work.

Thanking you, we remain,

Yours truly,
Canadian Well Supply Company

Sir,

In response to my recent enquiry from several sources for a reliable well-driller in the vicinity of Regina, the name of your firm has been received.

The problem I have on hand at the present time is not the drilling of a new well but the cleaning out of a well supplying water to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Leestock, Sask., about 85 or 90 miles northeast of Regina.

Some of the history and behaviour of this well known as No.2 at the above school is as follows:

The well was drilled in 1930 by Mr. S. Dempsey, working for McPherson & Thom. Drilling proceeded to 92 ft. where hard water was found pumping 240 gallons per hour. This was not sufficient, so drilling proceeded to 145 ft. where 420 gallons per hour of softer water was found. When the bales was used everything appeared O.K. but when a pump with capacity of 600 gals. per hour was used the well plugged with mud and sand. Mr. Dempsey thought if a smaller pump with had been used allowing the water to enter the casing more slowly, it might have been better as the mud would not have been drawn in by the pressure. However, this is supposition. Dempsey then quit. The well "plugged" Shortly afterwards, so he tried again. He would not help matters so he drilled to 204 ft. and later to 225 ft. he found it dry at 225 ft. He then pulled the casing to the 90 foot vein and filled the hole from 225 feet to 90 feet with gravel.

A 7 foot screen was placed at 142 feet but plugged so it was never replaced. It at present is stored in its original box in the implement shed at the school, and on recent examination found that the slits were enlarged by a hacksaw in an attempt to stop plugging.

The casing now stands at the 91 foot vein consequently the water at present obtained is possibly a mixture of the 142 foot and 90 foot water.

While our engineer was present on June 16 about 400 gals. was pumped in 3½ hrs., or about 100 gals. per hour showing that the well was by no means completely plugged, and yet badly short of 400 gals. as desired.

The well pumped some mud near the beginning of its life. It was hardly ever clear for the first Canadian Well Supply Co., Regina, Sask.

Memorandum:

The Honourable, the Superintendent General,

They are experiencing considerable difficulty with the water supply system at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, Sask., due to shortage of water in the well. The Dominion Water Power Branch was asked to have their District Engineer examine the well and report as to whether it would be possible to clean it out or if necessary to drill a new well.

Information has been received from the Dominion Water Power Branch that it would cost $250.00 to clean out the old well, but that the two firms whom they asked to figure strongly advised against this procedure as they feared that the well would be completely ruined if disturbed. It therefore appears that a new well is necessary, and the cost of same will probably be in the neighborhood of $1,000.00.

It is rather difficult to make an estimate as the depth to which they would have to drill is not known.

The Dominion Water Power Branch Engineers obtained estimates from the Canadian Well Supply Company Ltd. of Regina and McPherson and Thom of Saskatoon.

There are no funds provided in this year's estimates for this work. The only funds that could be found at present would be to utilize some of the money provided under the Public Works Construction Act. There are two day schools, estimated at $3,000. each, - one of these schools could be left over for the present and the money used to meet emergencies such as now exists in the water supply system at the Muscowequan School.

If the work is to be proceeded with I would ask you to please advise me if the Canadian Well Supply Co. of Regina may be employed for the work.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

GENERAL

The material supplied, and the work done, in connection with the construction of the proposed deep well and basement at the above-named school are to be to the satisfaction of the Engineer-In-Charge, Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Calgary, Alberta.

Only material of the best quality is to be used, and workmanship is also to be of the best quality.

The school is situated between Punnichy and Lestock, Saskatchewan.

NATURE OF WORKS

The works consist of the drilling of a well about 150 feet deep for an 8" casing together with the construction of a reinforced concrete basement according to the blue print plan accompanying these specifications. The materials for the well consist of casing, pipe rods working head cylinder etc., in fact everything necessary for proper functioning of the water supply including all necessary electrical and pipe connections. The well is to be plumb and properly drilled and is to supply from 6000 to 7000 gallons per day of 4 hours.
CONCRETE

In addition, a reinforced concrete pit is to be properly and firmly attached to the existing brick work and stone work.

The footing is to be firmly constructed one foot wider all around than the walls. The walls and roof are to be water tight, being covered with an asphalting material.

The concrete shall consist of clean screened gravel, clean sand, with the addition of good Portland cement in the proportion of 5 of gravel, 3 of sand and 1 of cement for bottom and sides, and 4 of gravel, 2 of sand and 1 of cement for the roof. It shall be properly mixed before pouring in shallow layers and then well tamped and smoothed.

Reinforcement will be lapped and wired especially at corners. The ends should be bent. Care should be taken that correct lengths of reinforcing be obtained to prevent waste in cutting.

A hole with proper ridge and cover 20" square shall be left in the roof immediately above the well for possible future cleaning.

Connections shall be made with the existing system.

A properly sized door is to be cut into the powerhouse for ingress into new basement.

Muscowequan School

The price per foot in this case is $4.00 per foot flat price, as this well is only 145 feet deep. The drilling rig has to be shipped a long distance for a shallow well hence the unit price is greater. The 145 feet would therefore cost $580.00.

In this case also the two drillers will look after their own bed and board. This is the better plan when it can be arranged. Father Allard allowed Rahrick to use the old rectory free of charge. In the case of the Muscowequan School I expect that the men will board at the school as the village is several miles away, but they will make their own arrangements.

Paragraph 3

The statement "unit prices will prevail" referred to the well proper, the amount of casing, rods and pipe needed obviously depending on the depth of the well. It was included in order that there would be no misunderstanding regarding total price.

This statement possibly should have been placed immediately after "screen" as it has nothing to do with the basement itself. I did not notice this apparent fallacy when

writing the contract but Mr. Marshall of the Canadian Well Supply thoroughly understood what was intended, consequently no difficulties will occur in the matter.

Paragraph 4.

In the absence of any instructions from the Director regarding personnel of staff to build the basement (only a few days' work at most, and a simple job at least, because of the shape and size) it was necessary to attempt to make arrangements with Mr. D.E. Marshall of the Canadian Well Supply, to use his two drillers, together with one or two local men if needed, to construct the basement. Neither the necessary labour or material is sufficiently large to necessitate special arrangements.

I consequently instructed Mr. Marshall, in your name, to buy the small amount of lumber, cement, gravel and reinforcing steel necessary at a local point, the bills being sent to the Dominion Water Works Board. Both of these drillers are also experienced men at this sort of work and could do the job. The prices for material will be those prevailing at Lestock. The price of 50¢ per hour for foreman (the present head driller) and 25¢ per hour for labour (the present helper together with one or two local men if needed) includes the contractor's profit together with bed and board. I quoted these prices as those paid at Duck Lake School and Mr. Marshall was satisfied.

Paragraph 5.

The inconsistency of the latter report when compared with the former is only apparent, not real. When it was the only well available, tampering with the old one would be very dangerous in case the whole supply would be cut off. It seemed to me, however, that when a new well was drilled it would be advantageous to try to rehabilitate the old one.

I was aware of my former suggestion together with Mr. Marshall's, but the presence of a new well will improve the critical conditions.

We did not wish to tamper with the old well when it was the only one available.

It may be that the old well has more or less temporarily improved since my last visit, as no complaints have been received. If so, improvement will probably only be temporary and with a new well it might be a good move to attempt cleaning the old one. It is quite possible that the Indian Department will not agree with me and may wish to leave the old well as it is, hence my statement - "Unless otherwise advised".

1. Purpose of Report.

This report deals with the progress of the new well as ascertained during a visit made to the School on November 6, 1934 and follows an Interim Report dated August 20, 1934.

2. Present Condition.

The drillers were absent, having gone to Regina on November 5 to consult with D.B. Marshall of the Canadian Well Supply Co. re conditions found on the previous day. However, the writer proceeded to Regina after examining conditions around the well and consulted with all parties.

The log which is enclosed, in duplicate, will indicate the materials penetrated and may be compared with that at the old well drilled in 1930, two copies of the log of which are also attached.

The drillers of the present well found only a slight amount of water at the points indicated in the log. They then went on down to the 142 feet vein but found no gravel 3' thick as in the other well. Instead, the drill dropped abruptly as if through a hollow space or through very soft clay, probably the latter, according to the
drillers. They thought it was water at first. They found 60 feet of water in the hole on Sunday morning, November 3, after reaching this point but this was quickly bailed out and more returned very slowly; entirely too slowly for practical purposes.

It was thought that there are two possible reasons for the non-appearance of gravel at 142' - 5', viz:- either the gravel stratum is a lens which peters out before getting to the new well or that the gravel stratum dips between the two locations and that if they go, say 15 or 20 ft. more, they may strike the gravel stratum.

If this fails the new well can be drilled to 205 feet. It might be mentioned again that the old well was originally sunk to 205' and then filled with gravel to 92 ft.

After consultation at Regina, the driller returned to the School with the intention of drilling 15' or 20' more, then if there be no success, to continue to the 205'.

The casing in the new well is at present at 92 ft. Possibly the water in the old well from the 42' level goes down and joins the 142' water and also the 205' water which must come up. The drillers think that the bulk of the water in the old well comes from the 205' level up through the gravel. This gravel filling must be handled carefully with proper sized gravel. The hole being drilled is 8" in diameter, although Mr. Marshall thinks it is nearer 10" because of the bit.

3. Possible Operations.

(a) Drill another 15 or 20 feet in an effort to
intercept the 142' gravel stratum of the old well, or to prove that it has petered out.

(b) Go to the 205' level, similarly to the old well to find this water.

(c) Drill another well on the other (west) side of the old well at least 10' away to intercept the gravel seam. The drillers think that a cave has probably been formed for a short distance around the old well.

(d) Find another source. No sloughs or lakes are in the neighbourhood. The Canadian National Railway has a tank at Touchwood, five miles to the south west. The water for this tank comes from a source (spring or lake probably) 3 miles further south of the railway. It would appear that this would be only a last resort because of the expense.

4. Materials.

Mr. Marshall has not ordered the working head nor anything in connection with the pit until water is found. They can be quickly obtained when needed. He has ordered pump rods Cylinder 3" pipe. These materials are at Regina ready to be shipped.

5. Notes.

It might be mentioned that the toilet traps, etc., in the plumbing system are continually being choked and stopped up with fine sand and silt, necessitating constant attention.
Meanwhile the drillers are drilling further, possibly to the 205' point as water has to be obtained somewhere and in some way.

The water situation is similar all over Saskatchewan.

P.A. Fetterly

Further to conversation with Mr. Betterly when he was here last week. The well has now been drilled down to two hundred and five feet. What we would suggest doing is setting casing down between 140 ft. and 150 ft. then pouring gravel into the hole, this would prevent the clay from pulling into the pipe but we would still have the danger of the clay closing out on the outside of the gravel, nearly shutting off the water. Sir,

I have received your letters of the 15th and 16th instant with enclosures and your telegram of the 15th instant with reference to the well situation at Muscowequan Indian School, and Mr. Johnston of the Geological Survey has been consulted to find out what is the best plan to follow under the circumstances.

Mr. Johnston's advice is to the following effect. To begin with he does not think that there would be any advantage in deepening the well, as at a lower depth the water, if found, is likely to be saline and unfit for use. He suggests that the procedure to be adopted should be somewhat as follows:

(1) Test the well by bailing to find out the amount of water which it is likely to produce.

(2) Find out as nearly as possible the point at which the greatest flow of water is coming into the well. This would represent the level at which the well should be developed.

(3) If the well drillers are satisfied that the well is likely to produce a sufficient flow of water for the requirements of the school it will probably be necessary to insert a casing inside the present casing down to the level at which the water is entering the hole and at this point have a screen fixed on to the inner casing. (The type of screen recommended is that supplied by Edward E. Johnston, Inc., of 2304 Long Avenue, St. Paul, Minn.)

(4) It will probably also be necessary to lower the present casing to about the same level to prevent the well caving in on the inner casing and screen. The well drillers would be able to give an opinion on this point.

(5) The lower part of the well below the point at which the water is coming into it should be blocked up by a wooden or concrete block as may be found most satisfactory.

The cost of the inner casing and screen would probably be in the neighbourhood of $1,000, but I should be obliged if you would obtain prices for this material as delivered to the school.

Re Muscowequan Indian School,

In reply to yours of November 28 regarding the well at Lestock, I got in touch with the Engineer there, after I phoned you Wednesday morning and he promised to send a sample of water to you at Calgary. I had a letter from the Assistant Principal, this morning, advising that this sample had been sent forward.

In reply to your first question, which is in connection with the supply of water. Our 4 hour test run 450 gallons per hour, and I firmly believe that it would be considerably more than this, if pumped from the 40 foot level. That is, if a well were properly finished at 40 feet as what we were getting was falling down the outside of the casing to 135 ft.

Your second question was finding out the depth of greatest flow. We decided this point was 40 ft. on account of our check up of the lowering of the water in No.1 well.

Your third question in regard to using a smaller casing and screen, Mr. Johnston's suggestion to use the smaller casing for screening, would only be feasible providing the water had been coming in at a lower level than our 6" casing. Even then, I could not see the advantage of using this casing as the surface water was flowing down around the 6". The idea to prevent seeping was all right, but it would not work with the flow of water. There would no advantage to think of a scheme of this kind, if the well were to be finished at 40 ft. The blocking of the hole below the casing would be to prevent loss of water, providing there was a sand layer further down. This also answers Question No.4.

Your fifth question--I have already answered the reason for the wooden or concrete block. If a 6" casing were used, price of pipe f.o.b. Regina is $1.50 per ft. When I wrote to you last Thursday, I did not take the liberty of making any suggestions but, as you have asked for ideas on this subject, I would suggest the following:

When you were in the office here, about 3 weeks ago, I suggested that if no gravel was found in the hole we were drilling, that we would have to drill another well slightly west of the present No.2 well. My idea would be to put a 4 or 4½" test hole down there to 150 ft. and find out definitely if there was any gravel or water supply near that level. To do this successfully, we would use 8" casing to the 40 ft. level, driving this pipe without a shot to prevent the water was absolutely shut off and then continue with the small hole. If we found we had a water supply at the 140 or 150 ft., as stated in the log of the Well No.2 we would proceed to drill the 8" well at the regular price of $4.00 per ft. If nothing was found in the test hole, the price is $1.50 per ft. for drilling the small hole. Then again provided the water sample that we sent in is not too hard and can be handled with a softening plant, I would recommend using the old No.1 well, as I am quite sure the water is identically the same as that which we are getting out of the present drilled hole. This well has a first class concrete crib with pipe connections running into the powerhouse, and the only thing that might be necessary to do there, would be to deepen it slightly, probably 20 ft., to give a little more submergence for the pump. My idea would be to put in a 20 ft. length of pipe with the top end drilled or hack-sawed with a screen part at the top and with the openings left in the gravel formation. Then the pump and pumping equipment could be set above the surface over this well.
I believe this would be a more satisfactory arrangement than trying to finish the present 5" well and put in a concrete pit and all necessary connections from there. If this suggestion of the 4" test hole sounds reasonable to you, wire at once, and we will get the men started on this hole. In the meantime the authorities at Ottawa can decide definitely what should be done.

I will expect to hear from you shortly,

INTERIM REPORT ON WATER SITUATION at Muscowequan Indian School Lestock, Sask., by P.A. Fetterly, Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

A. Purpose of Report

It was decided that the writer should proceed immediately to Lestock to investigate the water situation at the above named school in accordance with the urgent request of Mr. Marshall of the Canadian Well Supply of Regina. Accordingly the writer proceeded to Regina on Wednesday, December 12, and then went by automobile with Mr. Marshall to Lestock 100 miles north east of Regina, arriving Thursday morning.

It was found that the drillers had been unable to do any constructive work for three weeks, at no cost to the Government.

B. Activities

The general situation was inspected, discussed and argued nearly all day with Mr. Marshall; the School Engineer, and the drillers. As you are aware, the 4" test hole nearer Well No. 2 to 150' depth was vetoed by Ottawa, by implication in the Director's letter to the Secretary of Department of Indian Affairs dated Dec. 6.

A personal visit was found to be the only
method of deciding on procedure. After many plans had been suggested and discarded it was decided to proceed on the following line, closely following the suggestions contained in the Director's letter of Dec.6:

(1) Finish the new well (No.3) at the 40' level or at the point where the greatest flow occurs. It was apparently intended by Ottawa that the complete concrete pit should not be constructed with machinery installed therein, but that a temporary installation should be made until the well was proved. The driller had inserted 40' of 8" casing and 3" pipe in the well with a cylinder installed and activated by the drilling machine, to be used as a temporary pump for testing purposes. Water was pumped for about 10 hours, and showed no signs of failing. The water was slightly silty. Two one-quart samples were obtained after pumping had proceeded for 6 or 7 hours.

The driller was then instructed to install the working head on the surface of the ground and to construct a temporary frost-proof structure over it very little larger than enough to cover it. The discharge pipe, about 4' long, would extend through the wall and downward 4' to connect with the existing system. Everything would be protected from frost. The cost of this temporary arrangement will
be very small.

The character of the water will not be known until the Calgary City Chemist performs the analysis, so that care will have to be taken in mixing this new water with that from Well No.2 which supplies the water for the boilers. This latter water does not appear to affect them. The waters cannot be kept separate as only one system of boilers and pressure tanks exists.

The writer tested the capacity of Well No.3. A 45 gallon barrel was filled in 6 min. 10 sec. This is nearly 450 gallons per hour.

It might be mentioned here that the pumping of water from No.3 lowered the level of the water in No.1, 20 feet away by nearly 4 feet temporarily. It did not affect No.2 well, which is 46 feet from Bo.3.

The question of a water softener for this water will best remain in abeyance as mentioned by the Director until the nature and amount of alkali salts in this water (No.3) are known. A water softener removes the Ca SO₄ and Mg SO₄ but does not help the Na₂SO₄ content to a great extent. This is because zeolite already contains Sodium ions.

(2) Recondition the old well.

This refers to the latter portion of the sixth paragraph of Mr. Marshall's letter of November 30, not to the first part referring to the 4" test hole experiment, the latter being vetoed by No.4 paragraph.
As it would not be possible to hold the drilling rig until No.3 had been proved, it was determined to prepare No.1 well for production of water. The Director's letter was not clear on this point. After No.3 had been conditioned the rig would either have to be removed to other work waiting for it or demurrage would have to be paid for since Mr. Marshall could not hold it idle any longer.

The driller was therefore instructed as follows:

Drill 1/4" holes 3/4" centres in the first 3 feet of a 20' length of 8" casing. Sink this in the bottom of the 40 foot hole of well No.1 which is lined with concrete tile 3' diameter by 2' long. Then replace the cover and leave until the results of No.3 are known. It may later be found that, instead of constructing a concrete pit at No.3 we may have to construct a house over No.1. The cost would be about the same. A quart sample of this water was obtained for analysis.

(3) Analysis of Water

Adequate samples were obtained from each of the three wells. These were taken to Calgary and to the City Chemist. He will not be able to perform the work until about Dec.22. Two copies will be sent to Ottawa and one to the school so the Engineer will know how to apportion production from the wells in order to protect his boilers.

(4) Another Well.

This refers to Mr. Marshall's suggestion in the
first portion of the 6th paragraph of his letter, and states that another well should not be contemplated at present.

C. Fate of No.2 Well

This matter was admittedly difficult to decide upon. This well is flowing fairly freely at present, although it diminishes at times. It also produces water which does not appear to harm boilers pressure tanks, plumbing, etc. Until the results from Nos.3 and 1 are fully known it is not considered desirable to interfere with this well. Mr. Marshall was of the same opinion although he would receive $100 for cleaning or attempted cleaning. No attempt will therefore be made to rehabilitate this well at present.

D. Additional Cost

Mr. Marshall was requested to give an estimate of the additional cost over the present total invoices of $1352.34 and $9.83. It was as follows:

Drilling and hacksawing "homemade" screen composed of 8" well casing, as above. 10.00

Drilling 20' in Well No.1 below 40' level 2 or 3 days @ $20 60.00

Cost of Working Head, already provided for but not in above invoice. 385.00

Installing Working head at Well No.3 including Shelter. 15.00

E. Conclusion

A difficult situation has been handled to the best of one's ability and judgment. Nothing is being
done that may afterwards prove harmful. Providing the water from Well No.3 is not too hard, a judicious mixture from Nos. 2 and 3 may prove to be the solution of the difficulty. If it were possible to keep the waters separate No.2 should be all right for boilers, etc., and No.3 for most domestic purposes. The analyses will decide this.

P.A. Fetterly,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

The engineer at this school, Mr. Doull, has had twelve years experience in operating equipment at our residential schools and is a very careful and conscientious worker. I have every confidence in him so far as the work and operation of the machinery is concerned, but I am not so sure of his ability in so far as the electrical equipment is concerned.

Dear Sirs:

When checking your plant at the Muscowequan Residential School, we find the batteries incapable of the services required of them. There has been some question as to why this battery has become inoperative and upon close inspection of some of the cells it appears that these cells have been allowed to become under charged and thus in a sulphated condition. A heavy over charge was given this battery to bring it back to normal instead of slow charge which caused the plates to warp and break and to dislodge active material, thereby shortening the life of the battery. We therefore recommend a new battery, the price of which is as follows:

INTERIM REPORT
ON
WATER SITUATION
at
MUSCOGEQUAN INDIAN SCHOOL
Lestock, Sask.,
by P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc.,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Purpose of Report

The writer combined an inspection visit to the above-named school with a hydrometric trip to Regina, on June 13, to ascertain progress. The Contractor, D.E. Marshall of Canadian Well Supply of Regina, accompanied him.

Results of Inspection

It was found that the driller had been ill for three weeks or more and had been unable to work. He expected, however, to begin on June 17 and to finish the concrete pit and installation of the pump in a short time.

The inspection, together with recent developments as to salt content of the water (from Well No.3) resulted in slight changes in design.

Owing to the nature of the water it was decided to make a direct connection between the pump on the new well and the outside open stock-watering tank in order that this water, at least, would not have to pass through the pressure tanks. As a considerable amount of water is used for this purpose a large saving in the potential deposit of salts in the plumbing system should be made. Livestock will not be
likely to refuse this undiluted water.

The change necessitated the extra purchase of two check valves and some piping. This will of course not obviate the necessity for using some of the water from Well No.3 in the school itself but the amount mixed with Well No.3 will be greatly lessened.

Father Jeanotte, the Principal, stated that, although they had been compelled to use the water sparingly, they had not actually suffered to any great extent. Rains are at present supplying some water in the sloughs for the stock. He also stated that he is constructing a concrete tank for conservation of rain water from the roofs.

The acute water situation at this school should be solved for some time to come when the present well has been connected with the water system.

It appears to one that a school having only one source of supply is in a precarious situation, particularly if this sole source consists of a well.

Sir:

Referring to my letter No. 312-11A RC dated June 5, with reference to the condition of the Batteries in conjunction with the electric lighting plant in the Muscowequan Residential School, in the Touchwood Agency.

I may advise the Department that I have again been approached by the authorities at the School, who inform me that the Batteries are becoming very poor and it is extremely difficult to keep them functioning. I had three of the cells brought in for examination and find that it is not possible to have them brought back to normal. The plates are in a badly sulphated condition and warped. This is due no doubt to the Batteries having been allowed to become over-charged and thus in a sulphated condition. A heavy over-charge was given these Batteries to bring them back into service instead of a low charge, which caused the plates to warp and break thereby discharging active material and shortening the life of the Batteries.

The Battery recommended for this plant is the same as that which is being purchased for the Gordon Residential School and will cost practically the same, about $577.00. I am of the opinion that the engine should be examined and over-hauled. This unit has been in use for a considerable time. It was transferred from the Edmonton Residential School to Lestock.

In the event of authority being given for the purchase of the battery, I would advise that the matter be placed in the hands of the Mumford, Medland Limited, of Winnipeg who are the Western Agents for the Lister Plants. They submitted the best bid on the Battery for the Gordon School and recently over-hauled the engine at that point for a very reasonable figure.

I would be glad to have the Department's decision regarding this matter as soon as it is convenient as it is important that this work should be done before the children return from their holidays.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School requests that the Department give consideration to the following items for the school; they were noted in my estimates for 1936-37 page 9 under allotment 243.

1. Construction of a building for laundry, I estimated for $2,000.00, however if the laundry is to be built the architect will have to say what sort of place will be constructed. Some years ago a laundry was being fitted up in an old building here at the time the place went off fire, since then the work has been done in an old hen house, entirely unsatisfactory and unhealthy. I beg to recommend that this building be considered. The principal already has the soft water tank constructed as a foundation on the site against side of the school.

2. Construction of building for granary with drive way down centre, I estimated for $800.00. This building is required as the old place in use is falling down.

3. $25.00 of cement for foundations for the pig pen. I did not estimate for this item but the cement is required.

Ottawa, March 26, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, that funds be provided to erect a building for laundry purposes and a granary.

On October 31st, 1935, your Mr. Montgomery wrote Mr. Morrison, then of this office, advising him that he had just returned from a trip to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School at Lestock and had over-hauled their Lister Generating plant.

Mr. Montgomery is no doubt quite familiar with this plant and I therefore wish to place this matter before him for his opinion and recommendations.

We have had considerable trouble and expense in connection with this plant and wish to arrive at some solution to the question. In December, 1934, this generator burned out and had to be re-wound at quite an expense and again in January of this year at a cost of $160.00. I am today in receipt of a report from the Engineer at the school, stating that the generator is apparently running too hot and may again burn out. I am enclosing a copy of the Engineer's report.

In your letter referred to you state that "no doubt if rheostats were installed they would eliminate the difficulty experienced with regulations of voltage, if the speed of the engine was not altered at the governor, as the light load varied". Do you consider that the installation of rheostats will eliminate our trouble? I shall be glad if you will please write the Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa direct, giving them your views, forwarding me a copy of your letter, setting out the type of rheostat required and cost F.O.B. Lestock.

Yours truly,

Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sirs:

With reference to your letter of February 5th, which we must apologize for not answering previously, due to Mr. Montgomery being out of town. The writer has discussed the situation with him on his return in order to get the complete picture and history.

Apparently the work done by Mr. Montgomery was subsequent to the first rewind but prior to the second rewind, and since this rewind job was done external to our firm, it is of course impossible for us to take any responsibility for it. Providing, however, that this was carried out satisfactorily both from a point of view of workmanship and material put into it, the Generator should operate entirely satisfactorily.

The report of the Engineer and Principal at Lestock dated January 28th appears to be in order and just what we would expect to happen. Both Battery and Generator would be designed for a voltage around 150 or 180 volts.

Your letter states that the Plant is apparently running too hot and may burn out again. However, from the Engineer's report it would appear that the Generator is running fairly cool and in this connection it should be borne in mind that a Generator has a temperature rise of 72 deg. F. over and above the surrounding atmosphere, so that if the atmospheric temperature of the room is 70 deg. F. then 70 plus 72 is 142 deg. F., which is the temperature that would be normally expected on the coils and commutator of the Generator. Since this temperature is above that which the normal hand can bear, it will be understood that this machinery will no doubt feel considerably hotter than is comfortable for the hand.

(Cont'd)
Department of Indian Affairs,

We trust this information will be of help to you and if we can be of any further assistance please let us know.

Yours very truly,

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED,

Manager, Electrical Department.

Dear Sir:

Re letter 312-11A R.C. of March 8th last asking if rheostat for the electric light plant at Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I beg to say I went down to the school this week and talked this matter over with the engineer.

Mr. Doll says that in his opinion we require the rheostat. He had not operated the big engine all winter; he was waiting to get these appliances, however, in view of the opinion expressed by the Mumford, Medland Limited I told him to use the plant but to be careful and watch it when in operation.

You may not know it so I will give you more history of this plant. At one time it was the plant used at the big school near Edmonton; it was taken out and stored away. I heard the school got the high power or some other means of obtaining electricity, it may have been giving trouble at that time for anything I know. They about six years ago it was sent here and put in the Muscowequan School and has been giving trouble ever since.

Sir:-

I beg to report upon the lighting plant at the Muscowequan Residential School, Touchwood Agency.

In 1931 the Lister lighting plant formerly in use at the Edmonton Residential School was transferred and installed in the Muscowequan School. It is a 6 K.W. plant. Since its installation it is reported that it has never given satisfactory service. In December, 1934, the generator burned out and again this past winter at an expense of $160.00. There has been considerable correspondence between this office, the Mumford, Medland, Limited, Winnipeg, (Agents for the Lister equipment), the Magneto Service Station, and the Engineer at the School as to whether or not the installation of rheostats would eliminate some of the trouble. At the present time the 6 K.W. plant is not being used, as the Engineer is afraid of the generator again burning out, and they have a small 3 K.W. plant there which they are using. I am enclosing herewith a letter received from Mr. Waddy today in this connection.

The Mumford, Medland, Limited have not inspected this plant since the generator was rewound this winter and are therefore not in a position to state whether the rheostats would be of benefit. Would it be in order for me to have their Inspector visit the Muscowequan School if he is near Lestock in the near future?

Your obedient servant,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

The Mother Superior informs me that in view of the great utility of this knitting machine she would forego, for the time being, the "tailor" machine which has been promised the School in return for a knitting machine.

It may be said that knitting machines will not be provided our Indian girls on the reserves after they leave the School and that, therefore, they should not be supplied to Boarding Schools and that the girls should rather be taught how to knit. The argument has, no doubt, a great deal of value. On the other hand, it must be remembered that it would be too great a burden to impose on the School girls to ask them to knit stockings for a staff and pupilage of over 100 individuals. My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing Plans for the proposed laundry building for the Lestock School. Mr. Hoey expressed the opinion that it might be better to put up a separate building for this purpose, but the Sisters in charge of the school refuse to listen to this plan; and you know what women are like! You can refuse a request of theirs for a short time, but in the end they always win out. That is what happened at Lestock. In order to satisfy the Sisters, and possibly their viewpoint is the right one, we shall have to build the laundry alongside of the school, on the East side of the chapel. If I remember well, it will be very convenient on account of the proximity of the boiler room and the soft water cistern. The reason I am sending you the Plans at home is that I would like you to break the news gently to Mr. Hoey so that we may not meet with any opposition on his part.

In view of the fact that the estimates may not be voted before June, and that considerable time might elapse after they are voted before we can proceed with the construction of this new laundry, Very Reverend Father Lamontagne suggests going ahead with the building as soon as the ground has thawed out and advance the money out of the Provincial funds, and have the Department pay the accounts after the Indian estimates have been passed by the House. I did not want to send my letter directly to the Department for fear that it might get in the hands of some of the higher officials and from there into the hands of the Engineers' Dept.; if that happened you know what would be the consequences as far as the laundry building is concerned: It would not see the light of day before 1939. I hope that you will do all you can to meet with the wishes of Very Reverend Father Lamontagne.

We are all extremely pleased in our Oblate circles with the appointment of Very Rev. Father Langlois to the See of Grouard. He knows the Indian problem better than most, and his permanent presence on our Committee will be a great source of strength for us all.

With renewed thanks and good wishes, I remain

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Father Poulin, O.M.I., who is looking after the Muscowequan School during the absence of the Principal who is on holidays, called on me yesterday and informed me that the roof of the school was leaking in several places and should be repaired. The Father was accompanied by a Brother Gauthier who is a competent builder. They informed me that within a week or ten days they were taking men from Regina to put the roof on the Laundry they are building, and asked authority to have the roof of the school repaired while these men were there, as it could then be done at a much lower cost.

I questioned Brother Gauthier as to its necessity and cost. He informed me that the roof started to leak this Spring. Water comes through the plaster and drops on the floor when it rains, and he states that there will be considerable damage done to the plaster unless the roof is repaired. With regard to the cost, he stated that it would be impossible to give a definite figure as the work necessary could not be ascertained until the repairs were under way. He stated, however, that he did not think it would be in excess of $50.00.

They also took up the matter of the necessity for a drier for drying clothes being supplied for the Laundry. The Brother stated that the driers in general use were very expensive, costing in the neighbourhood of $1800.00, but that there was a drier being manufactured in Winnipeg under the name of the "Utility Drier" which would serve the purpose and which could be purchased at a cost of $700.00. He asked that this drier be supplied to the school.

I would recommend that authority be given for the repairs to this roof at the earliest possible date in order that the work may be done while the men are there. With regard to the drier, there is no doubt that it is necessary, and I would recommend that it be given consideration if funds are available.

I might state further that Father Poulin brought me a letter from Mr. Waddy, Agent, covering this matter.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.

REPORT re: REPAIRS TO ROOF

MUSCOGEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
Lestock, Saskatchewan

The roof of the Muscogequan Indian Residential School was inspected on September 24th, 1938, and I found the following conditions:

The roof on the main building and the two large dormitories is in poor condition, which will require replacement. The roof on the powerhouse, though somewhat better in appearance, has also several leaks through which water finds its way and in turn has caused cracks to develop in the ceiling from the interior. The roof on the chapel is also in a similar condition and will require repairs.

The roof on the garage and approximately one-third of the area on the bakery has been repaired this year with an application of new asphalt and repairs to flashing at the walls. However, if the flashing acts as it has done on the main building, this repair work may be only considered temporary. The enclosed photograph taken during the inspection clearly shows what has taken place.

The flashing at the walls is in very poor condition. Much of the solder at the seams is gone, leaving open joints; and in many places the flashing has pulled out of the wall, allowing water to get in between the flashing and the brick wall. Due to the fact that this flashing has only a 3/4" face set in the wall, this is not of sufficient width to be held by the mortar.

At these sections of the roof, where the flashing has pulled out, ridges and hollows have formed in the roofing after movement had taken place down towards the drains. At these portions of the roof in particular some of the tar and gravel has been lost, requiring replacement of the roofing.

It appears that some of the water flowing between the wall and the flashing soaks underneath the roofing felt, causing the formation of the ridges and hollows in it. Furthermore it may be said that the cause of the roof damage is due to the flashing pulling out of the walls. To substantiate this it was noticed that at sections where the flashing is intact and still held in the wall the roofing surface is in much better condition, with no wrinkles in it. On the other hand where the flashing is no longer serving the purpose much damage to the roofing has been done.

The drains are in good condition and will not require much repair, with the exception of providing new copper wire screens and gravel stops.

To properly repair the roof, new roofing felt and asphalt should be put on the whole roof, replacing the present one, as it does not seem possible that only portions of the roof could be replaced to have a waterproof and durable surface.

To prevent a similar re-occurrence in the roofing, however, new flashing, with a wider face embedded in the brick mortar, should be used. The enclosed sketch shows a suggested type of flashing to be used. A 4" bearing surface should be provided as the wall is 6" wide, built of two rows of bricks, which will permit this change. The mortar can be chipped out with a special...
with a special tool and, after the new flashing is set, new mortar will be well tamped in. This new flashing should stand up. All flashing seams should be locked and soldered from the outside. The felt roofing should be laid as per original specifications. However a 2" x 4" cut diagonally into a wedge and laid as shown on the sketch should be used as at present only a ship lap set an angle to the sheathing supports the ends of the roofing felt.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your recent letter regarding the Lestock School Laundry.

A word of explanation, regarding the laundry building which we have just erected, may be in order and may help to clear the atmosphere of doubt and uncertainty which has prevailed in Ottawa, regarding its necessity as well as regarding its cost.

The Lestock or Muscowequan School was erected by the Department in 1929-30. It is a very substantial building and fully answers the purpose for which it was erected. For reasons I do not know no laundry quarters were provided in the new building. The machinery then in use was housed in the old school building and, to a certain extent, this arrangement was satisfactory; at least the school authorities did not lodge any formal complaints with the Department. Unfortunately, the old school building was destroyed by fire in 1931 and the laundry quarters were, of course, destroyed at the same time. A formal request was immediately placed before the Department for a building suitable for laundry purposes. The request was totally ignored although the ordinary phrase used in such circumstances was made use of, i.e. favourable consideration was promised the request. In the meantime what laundry machinery could be procured were housed in an old chicken house which had been discarded because it was deemed unfit for chickens. It was temporarily and very inadequately repaired and served the purpose of a laundry until our new laundry was put into operation last September. This old building was so unfit for the purpose for which it was used that one of the Sisters on the school staff contracted tuberculosis from repeated attacks of the grippe contracted during her work in the laundry and several of the girl pupils were seriously ill at different periods during the time this building was in use. The Reverend Sister has had to be confined to a sanatorium and is still under treatment.
The above facts are recited to explain to some degree the haste that took place last spring when it was understood that it was the intention of the Department to provide funds for the construction of the laundry. While your present purchasing system may have some advantages, it has a very decided tendency to delay receipt of purchases made through this system. I was afraid that this would happen in the case of the Lestock School laundry, so I took the bull by the horns and as soon as I was informed that it was your intention to provide funds for this project I went ahead, bought the materials, hired workmen and proceeded with erection of the building. As a consequence by the end of August, the laundry was fully completed, a real good job had been made of it, the laundry machinery was installed, and everything was in first order for the beginning of the school year. Had I waited for your system to get into motion I am inclined to feel that supplies would not have arrived in time to permit the building being erected in the fine weather -- which I feel you will admit is most desirable in Western Canada. I think that in acting as I did I rendered the Department real service and I should be blamed but rather congratulated for my quick and decisive action.

The laundry, which I have put up conforms in every respect to the fine school building which your Department erected; it is fireproof, well lighted, well ventilated and I doubt if your Engineers' Department could have done as well. They certainly could not have put up the building for the amount which I spent, for instance, the supervisor, a first class mechanic, received only $15.00 per week, the bricklayer received the same rate of pay and all the common labour was done by the old boys of the school assisted by some former pupils. Had this job been done by your Engineers' Department my older pupils as well as my former pupils would have been meticulously excluded from the job and all the fine theories of the Department, regarding manual training and the employment of the Indian labour, would have been blown to the four winds.

The invoices which I submitted to the Department are not all for the new building, quite a large sum is for equipment which you would have had to provide, in any case, even if a new building had not been erected. May I, in conclusion, say that I am proud of what I have done and I am exceedingly surprised that instead of receiving the praise and commendation of the Department I should be as severely
blamed as I have been. What is the use of the men in the field doing their best for our Indians and for the Department if that is the way their efforts are going to be appreciated.

I hope that this letter will clear up the situation and that in spite of the many and arduous duties which you have to perform daily you will find the necessary time to have cheques issued in payment of all the invoices which I have forwarded to you, in connection with the splendid laundry building which I erected for the Government owned Indian Residential School of Muscowequan.

With very best wishes, I am

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Geo. Jeannotte, O.M.I.,
Principal.

The Lestock or Muscowequan School was erected by the Department in 1929-30. It is a very substantial building and fully answers the purpose for which it was erected. For reasons I do not know no laundry quarters were provided in the new building. The machinery then in use was housed in the old school building and, to a certain extent, this arrangement was satisfactory; at least the school authorities did not lodge any formal complaints with the Department. Unfortunately, the old school building was destroyed by fire in 1931 and the laundry quarters were, of course, destroyed at the same time. A formal request was immediately placed before the Department for a building suitable for laundry purposes. The request was totally ignored although the ordinary phrase used in such circumstances was made use of, i.e., favourable consideration was promised the request. In the meantime what laundry machinery could be procured were housed in an old chicken house which had been discarded because it was deemed unfit for chickens. It was temporarily and very inadequately repaired and served the purpose of a laundry until our new laundry was put into operation last September. This old building was so unfit for the purpose for which it was used that one of the Sisters on the school staff contracted tuberculosis from repeated attacks of the grippe contracted during her work in the laundry and several of the girl pupils were seriously ill at different periods during the time this building was in use. The Reverend Sister has had to be confined to a sanatorium and is still under treatment.

Dear Sir;-

Re bed mattresses-Muscowequan School.

I have the honor to report that two weeks ago the principal of Muscowequan Indian Residential School told me he was going to write and ask that 12 mattresses be supplied him for the twelve beds shipped to the school in July. Just after he spoke to me the principal was admitted to hospital in St. Boniface with typhoid and it is probable that he never wrote about the mattresses.

As I know it was his intention to write will you please consider the matter and if possible arrange that the school be supplied with 12 mattresses for the beds. You will know the size from the beds ordered, I think they are six foot by thirty inches, but not certain.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, September 16, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 15th instant, in which you state that two drain pipes in the sewage system at the Muscowequan Residential School were blocked with scale and that you were compelled to take certain steps to remedy the condition.

In view of the emergency existing, the action taken by you is approved by the Department. However, the Department would like to have from you at the earliest possible date a summary of the work undertaken and the approximate cost. In view of the conditions now confronting us, it will be necessary for Indian agents and the principals of residential schools to co-operate with the Department in keeping expenditures down to the lowest possible figure.

It is my understanding that you have already sent on a statement of the repairs to be undertaken to the office of the Inspector at Regina.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Dear Sir,

Re letter 121-5-5 of Sept 16th regards blockage of drain pipes in Muscowequan School, I beg to say I got Carter of Yorkton to send a plumber to the school on the 16th and I went over the job with him. We found that all the soil pipes in the building above the basement floor were full of sediment which seems to be cemented right onto the pipes, the pipes from basement to outside the building appear to be clear.

There was so much wrong that I just got the plumber to make out a list of materials required to fix it and sent him back to Yorkton and this morning I talked to the manager of the Carter firm and he told me it looks like a $500.00 job, they do not know themselves. I then called up Inspector Robertson who is at work again and gave him an outline of the trouble. We know we have to install 12 clean outs and may have to put in new pipes also; cannot say until we find out if we can get that cemented sediment out of the present pipes.

The sediment comes from the chemicals in the water at the school.

The job has to be done and Carter has the equipment and men to do it, but these jobs cannot be estimated on, we are in the hands of the plumber more or less.

Your obedient servant,

R.A.Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been asked by Rev. Father Jeannotte, Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, who is now in the St. Boniface Hospital recuperating from an attack of typhoid fever, to acknowledge your letter addressed to him and dated September 12, 1939. Father Jeannotte informs me that the refrigeration system which was installed in the school by the Department is in operation, but that ice is used for refrigeration instead of the ice-making machine. The reason for this is that there is no electrical service in that district and that electricity is generated by a gasoline engine which it is too expensive to operate in conjunction with a refrigeration plant.

The outbreak of typhoid fever which took place in the school could hardly have been caused by the use of ice in the refrigerator as no food, butter or milk comes in direct contact with the ice. It has been well established by the medical authorities of the province of Saskatchewan that this outbreak of typhoid fever was caused by drinking ice water made with ice taken from a slough, the water of which was found upon analysis to be infected with typhoid germs.

All the ice which was left in the ice house, after its analysis had proven it to be affected, was thrown away and no more ice will naturally be taken from the infected slough. Next winter the ice for the school will be taken out of a nearby lake, the water of which, I am informed has been analysed and found to be free of all germs.
Should the province of Saskatchewan extend its hydro service along the highway into the village of Lestock, it is to be hoped that the Department will agree to install it in the school so that the present refrigeration plant may be put in use.

Hoping that the above explanation will be satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

As requested by you we have made an inspection of the refrigeration equipment at the above school, and beg a report as follows:

This installation was originally automatic in operation and as the power units in the powerhouse are also automatic it meant that when the one-half power motor operating the refrigeration compressor was cut in by the automatic valve, it automatically started the operation of the smallest of the gas engines units, which I believe is a 6 hp. (am not absolutely certain on this size so perhaps it had better be checked) with the consequence that during the day at least this gas engine would be running for no other purpose than to supply current to the one-half hp. motor on the compressor; naturally this would put the monthly costs rather high, in fact too high, we believe to be warranted.

Our recommendation is that the automatic feature of this installation be discontinued, and that the one-half motor be supplied or operated either by a small gas generator or a small gas engine of the required size. It will of course be possible to retain the automatic features if an automatic gas operated generator is installed, however we doubt very much if the retaining of automatic operation is of any great importance due to the fact that the walk-in box is not in constant use all day as it is in say a restaurant, our idea is that with a small individual plant manually operated this could be run during the preparation and serving of each meal and the hold over in the urine tanks should be sufficient (except in very hot weather) to take care of the food properly in between these runs, the only other run would be the night run at from 9 to ten o'clock.

Dear Mr. Waddy:

Since writing you yesterday, I have been doing some detail figuring on the set up at the school and from the results am wondering if the job ever did give satisfactory service. My figures indicate that it should have a 3/4 hp motor and not less than twice the present brine tank capacity with this set up the following operation would be necessary six hours in the morning and six hours in the late evening say from five to eleven. I did not go into the job as fully at first as I just assumed that it originally gave proper results, and now I am wondering, however I may be wrong and of course you will know.

In view of the above do you think my letter dated yesterday should go forward to Ottawa or should we submit another proposal? That will depend of course on what sort of a job was done before by the unit, and how long it ran. Perhaps it may be as well to let it go forward and in this way open the matter up and if we get the go-ahead signal we can then submit a more detailed proposition. The only objection to this is that Ottawa may take from the letter already sent you that we propose to use the existing compressor (although we do not say so definitely) while if my figures are correct as given above, we may have to state in our subsequent proposals (if any) that the capacity of the equipment would have to be increased, which might not sit well on their minds in the least. However as we say this all hinges on whether or not it was originally satisfactory, if it was, then the suggestions we have made are in order.

I will be glad to hear from you as to what you think.

Yours truly,
