Dear Sir,

Re letter 121-5-5 of April 8th last about frigidaire plant at Muscowequan Indian Residential School you say you were informed that the motor overheats to a point where the water in the system is changed into steam etc.

On making enquiry into this matter I feel you must have been misinformed, in fact when you read the enclosed report you may think you are reading about some other place, there is no motor there at all, how could it heat?

Here is part of the report.

Some years ago the principal found that the cost of running the frigidaire plant was too high, the little motor at the frigidaire place was very small, but to start it running the large gasoline lighting plant had to start up, it turned on automatically. Therefore whenever the door of the frigidaire room was opened on went the plant.

The principal therefore disconnected the electric part and put the brine tank out of commission, he placed an ordinary tank in the room used for refrigeration and kept it full of ice, not very satisfactory but cheaper than the other system. This kept on till last year when the ice was contaminated and the staff got typhoid; the plant is still using the ice system.

I had two inspections made here by Mr. Chapman of the Chapman Electric Co. Ltd. of Yorkton, Sask., he made the inspections when he was in the district. I told him I had no money to spend but to look the place over and then give me a short report and if you thought fit he might be authorised to make full report of cost of starting the place going again, and might get the work, but that I could promise nothing.

Now about that heating motor. That is good. Some time ago the principal had a man working on the laundry or some other work; the man saw the motor—½ horse power—said he would like it, and he got it. Simple as that. The principal gave it to him. The motor is missing altogether.

To make a long story short, this place needs a small gas engine to run a small motor that runs the compressor; also the place needs one or two more brine tanks. Mr. Chapman thinks the motor should be run occasionally, not every time the door opens, therefore run the engine a certain number of hours daily, start it manually not automatically.

The principal asks that if this system is operated that the room be divided so it is all one now. He says some food tastes the milk and butter when they are all in one place, his idea seems reasonable.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to report that the batteries used in the light plant at Muscowequan Indian Residential School are used up. I checked up at this place yesterday with an electrical engineer to find what was wrong.

These batteries were purchased in August 1935 from Mumford Medland, Winnipeg, Man., voucher 397 dated Nov 20 1935 settled this account.

56 cells, 13 plate, 252 amp hours, heavy duty.

On inspection we found the complaint was that the batteries would not hold electricity, each morning they were dead. The batteries are full of the sediment which deposits in them and are used up. They have given good service and have not been abused except that they have had to stand up to a lot of work.

The engineer at the school and the man I had with me both say that if new batteries are supplied they should be of the 300 amp hour type.

Globelite Batteries Limited informed me some time ago that they charge about $455.00 for a set of the 252 amp hour batteries F.O.B.Winnipeg,Man., this is quite a lot lower than we pay elsewhere, the charge for 300 amp hour batteries would be higher and we would have freight to pay, we could get a local engineer to install the batteries much cheaper than having a man come from the factory and put them in.

I beg to recommend that the school be supplied with the batteries before the old ones stop charging altogether.

Your obedient servant,

Report on the Muscowequan Indian Residential School

I wish to bring to your attention that while I was at the Touchwood Agency I visited the Muscowequan Indian Residential School on the 10th instant, where I spent about four hours.

I found everything in very good shape at this Institution. Everything was in good order, the main building in good state of repair, and the furnishings and furniture well taken care of. The only complaint I had there was regarding the roof of the building. This, as you know, is a flat roof and was guaranteed for seven years but since it is longer than that when the School was erected the guarantee does not hold any longer. Last Fall we purchased 125 gallons of mixture with which to repair the roof but it has not as yet been put on. However, when completed the roof will probably do for another year or so but it will not be long until the roof of this Institution will have to be renewed.

The out-buildings at this School were built years ago and some of them are getting the worse for wear and paint, but all are kept in fair shape by the Principal. The only new building that has been erected is the Laundry. When funds are available a new granary will have to be provided as the one they have now is becoming practically useless, but by repairing it every year we can make it do until the money is easier to obtain than it is at the present time. The only thing that has to be supplied is linoleum for the kitchen. The linoleum that has been on this is pretty well worn out and the Sisters informed me that it is very hard on their feet walking around on the cement floor. Fifty-five square yards of "Settleship" linoleum will be required and I hope that this will be allowed before another winter sets in.

I was in the dining room when the children were having their lunch and they seemed to be well fed and all looked happy and bright. There was no one sick, and there are 111 children in residence.........
The children have an ample supply of milk as they have 68 head of cattle at the School, 26 horses, 26 pigs, and 300 chickens. The School operates 2½ sections of land.

Taking everything into consideration I think this is a very well managed Institution and from the appearance of the children I consider that they are well taken care of by an efficient Staff.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School
Lestock, Saskatchewan

Further to my memorandum of the 21st ultimo regarding the above, I may say that as arranged, Mr. Gow carried out an inspection of the roof on the 22nd ultimo and we are now in receipt of his report dated the 5th instant. Mr. Gow states that the roofing on the main building, consisting of a central block and two wings, is in a very bad state of repair, the roofing being wrinkled and cracked, with considerable separation between the layers of felt; in spots the roof boards under the roofing are exposed. Much of the gravel has been removed by school employees, in attempting to carry out repairs which have proved ineffectual. The roofing is not properly bonded to the walls and other vertical surfaces, and as a result has pulled out from under the flashings. Mr. Gow considers that new roofing over the whole area will be necessary.

The flashings, while loosened and out of position, are in good condition and for the most part can be re-used. The condition of the bevelled cant strip will not be known until the roofing is removed.

Leakage has occurred through the roof and has become evident in the dormitory ceilings, but up to the present the damage has not been extensive or serious.

Mr. Gow estimates that the expenditure involved in replacing the existing roof on the main building only, with a four ply felt and gravel roof, having a guaranteed life of 15 years, and re-laying existing flashing as far as practicable, to be in the neighbourhood of $600.00. This amount would include all new materials required, labour, freight and engineering expenses. Repairs to interior plaster work, necessitated by roof leakage, are estimated to cost approximately $50.00, and are not included in the above figure.

To obtain the best results, it is recommended that the roofing and flashing work be carried out by contract under supervision of an engineer, and that Mr. Gow be authorized to obtain tenders from at least three approved contractors from Regina. The tenders would be based on specifications prepared by this service, and would include the provision of a bond covering the life of the new roofing.

As regards..........

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that the principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School had me look at one of his boilers last week. I went to the school and found he had disconnected the boiler altogether, had taken out one of the tubes and the condition of the boiler could be seen. The tubes are eaten out about half way in, they should be replaced. When looking at the boiler the engineer remarked that the crown sheet, which holds the end of the tubes better, was also about finished through action of minerals in the water.

This meant that just putting in tubes would be a waste of money.

E.H. Carter of Yorkton is sending two boilermakers to Gordon School tomorrow and they will call in at Muscowequan School and report to me on this boiler, which is the high pressure boiler with 48 tubes, 2" x 3", we may have to buy a new boiler if the crown sheet is gone.

Further report will be made to you when the men examine the boiler.

Dear Sir,

For some months we have had trouble with the large heating boiler at Muscoweguan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask., which appears to be used principally for the bath water. When I started in check up on costs the price quoted me looked so out of reason that I stalled on the whole matter till we could get further details, besides I know how your funds lack much balance just now.

The principal and the plumbing people who know the boiler say it is pitted too badly to be repaired, all I know is that it is dripping water from many spots all the time.

The last proposition we took up and have discussed with all concerned is that a 500 gal tank instead of a 750 one be put in, that the school be supplied with certain shower bath piping etc and the work done by the school engineer. This would entail supply of following materials etc.

1- 500 gal hot water tank with man hole etc.
200' ½" gal pipe
16- ¼" x 4" long galv nipples
20- ¼" galv Tees
40- ¼" 90 degrees gal elbows
20- ¼" 45 "
20- shower heads 4" for ½" pipe
5- shower drainers ¼" pipe
12 globe valves ¼"(pemberthy'COMPODISK' with removable seat)

I still dislike recommending all the above but there does not seem to any way out of it.

Would you consider writing a hard up letter to the principal and asking him if it is not in some way possible to get along with present outfit till after next April 1st, I know you have just paid out for complete new roof for this place. Rev. Jeannotte is reasonable at all times, but I have stood him off so long now that it might be well for someone else to taffy him along for a time, though I hate to ask you to do it.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the boiler at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. We have already expended an amount of nearly $2000.00 for repairs and improvements at this school this year. This is considerably more than the amount we intended to expend and under these circumstances it is practically impossible for us to consider the installation of a new heating boiler at the present time.

There is also the additional fact that due to present conditions it is unlikely that the delivery of a boiler could be secured for several months. The Surveys & Engineering Branch point out that it is doubtful if a 500 gallon tank would meet the requirements of the school. Taking everything into consideration I hope that the school will be able to carry on with the present boiler until the next fiscal year.

Yours truly,

EX'D.

Mr. G.A. Havers, In Charge Indian Agency, Punnichy, Sask.

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing requisition for materials for the Muscowequan Residential School. As you state in your letter, Mr. Davis forwarded a requisition on November 23 and we wrote to him on November 30 pointing out that we did not favourably consider the request made on the requisition and at that time we asked Mr. Davis to discuss the matter very carefully with the Principal. We also instructed him in the last paragraph of our letter of November 30 to let us know the name and address of the firm from whom any quotations were obtained. There has been so much delay in replying to our letter of November 30 that it is almost impossible for us to favourably consider such a large expenditure at the Muscowequan School at the present period of the fiscal year. I note from your letter that you have not discussed the requisition with the Principal and I should appreciate it if you would do so. For instance, the first items cover paint for farm buildings. While painting these buildings would no doubt give them a better appearance, I doubt the advisability of doing such work at the present time.

With regard to the repairs requested for the Kelvinator refrigerator, I should appreciate your advising when this was installed and the name of the firm from whom it was secured. The amount of lumber etc. requested is comparatively small, but the total cost amounts to over $50 and consequently purchase will have to be made through our Purchasing Branch. Re wiring in Barn at Muscowequan Indian School.

This wiring is in bad condition owing to the dampness and corrosive action of the dampness. The insulation is badly decomposed and the copper wire is eaten through in many places. The brass contacts in the sockets and switches are corroded as well.

Electrical Contractor.

August 31, 1944.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.

I have your letter of the 25th instant, enclosing voucher for $283.80 in connection with repairing the frigidaire at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

In your letter of April 17 you enclosed a quotation that you had received from Marshall-Wells Company Limited showing that the expenditure required would be $101.75 and purchase order No. 23771 was issued as a result of the recommendation contained in your letter.

Without authority I note that an expenditure of $283.80 has been incurred. It is simply impossible for the Department to control expenditures if school principals assume the responsibility of exceeding the amount which they are authorized to expend on repairs and improvements. Consequently we are forwarding Marshall-Wells Company a cheque for $101.75 and the Principal of the Muscowequan School should forward them a cheque for the balance; namely, $182.05. Please let me know when they have done so.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I wish to bring to your attention that the Saskatchewan Power Commission are extending their power line which will pass the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, and in all probability the school's source of electrical power will be changed from the present use of the lighting plant there connecting it with the power lines.

I have a letter from Mr. Simpson, our Indian Agent at File Hills, drawing this part to my attention and stating he would like to have the 110 volt plant that is now at the school transferred to the Agency. At the present time there is a 32 volt lighting plant at the Agency operated by an old type one-cylinder Delco engine connected to a set of 16 cells. Also, another plant of the same voltage is used at the File Hills Residential School which is operated by 3 K.W. 1-cylinder Delco engines attached to 16 cells. The Agent notes that it is difficult to get repairs for 32 volt plants as they are not as common as the 110 volt plants and he feels that more efficient service could be procured from the 110 volt plant. It is his understanding that if the plant from Muscowequan School could be transferred they could have sufficient power to supply the school as well as the Agency particularly if l/o or possibly 4/o weatherproof copper wire was used to carry the current from the plant to the buildings. The distance from the office to the residential school is about 550 yds. The plant could be installed in the old office building which is about 40 yds. from the present office, in fact this old building could be moved to any location that might be more suitable. The only work that will be necessary in this building is the construction of a cement foundation for the plant, also 1100 yds. of copper wire, 30 heavy insulators and brackets therefore and 15 telephone poles would be required. The Agent estimates it would cost $91.10 to do this work.

Before submitting this proposition to our Branch I have asked Mr. Simpson to contact the Inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission to look over the electrical wiring both at the school and at the Agency to see whether it would be in order to install this plant. I have a copy of the results of their inspection at my office and I notice that whether we transfer the plant and change the power to 110 volts or not some repairs would have to be made to the wiring at the Agency and school before continuing in the matter and I would like to be advised......
to be advised whether our Branch are prepared to recommend the transfer of the plant from the Muscowequan School after they are connected to the power line.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Electric Power Plant, Muscowequan Indian Residential School, your File No. 121-1-5.

Herewith is a letter received from Mr. Davis, Indian Agent, Touchwood Agency, requesting if it would be possible to transfer the batteries from the Muscowequan School to the Gordon's School. Mr. Davis states that the batteries at the Gordon School are in pretty bad shape and will have to be replaced at an early date.

I called the Muscowequan School and was informed that the batteries are in excellent condition but the two engines that operate the plant are old and will need repairs. I am given to understand that the motors at the Gordon School are in excellent condition and if Mr. Davis' suggestion is approved then their electric plant should be in good working order.

Your attention is drawn to Mr. Christianson's letter of October 3rd and your reply of October 11th, file No. 121-1-5. You may wish to give further consideration to Agent Simpson's request.

If the batteries are transferred to the Gordon Indian Residential School you will have two surplus Lester engines. One is a 27.5 amps, 5 h.p. which, according to report is in fair condition, and the other is a 55 amps, 10 h.p. which requires minor repairs. If the plant can be used as a unit in some other school it would not be wise to transfer the batteries to the Gordon School. However, the decision should be made at an early date as to what should be done with this plant as it is now not required at the Muscowequan School and will undoubtedly deteriorate if it is neglected. I am given to understand that one engine is being used to keep the batteries up. I should be pleased, therefore, if you would advise this office of your decision.

J. E. Morris,
Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Will you please wire reply so that I may have the work continued without interruption.

Ottawa, April 9, 1945.

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated February 28, 1945, Mr. J. E. Morris, who was then acting Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask., advised this office that owing to the Muscowequan School securing electrical power from the Provincial Power service, there were two surplus Lister engines at the school.

One of these engines is stated to be 27.5 amps. 5 H.P., in fair condition, and the other, 55 amps., 10 H.P., requiring minor repairs.

It is our intention to ship these engines to the Cariboo Indian Residential School in British Columbia, but, before doing so, we would like to have them placed in good condition. Can you have the necessary repairs done in Regina or some other place close to the Muscowequan School. The Department would appreciate it if you would make inquiries and let us know where you can have the work done, the approximate cost and the probable length of time it would require to place these machines in good condition. As soon as we hear from you, further instructions will be given to you and at that time we will also inform you of the correct address to which these two engines should be shipped.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

We just had a telephone call from Mr. Davis, the Indian Agent, from the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. The boiler at the school started leaking through faulty flues and, being an emergency case, it was decided to have the boiler sent in to Regina for repairs. However, it is the understanding that all of the flues in this boiler will have to be changed. We have the flues, 48 in number, and these will be sent in together with the boiler, but we would like to have authority from you for changing all of them as it will cost $1.25 a piece for taking them out and putting the new ones in, plus the freighting of the boiler from the school to Regina and back.

The total cost for repairing the boiler will, therefore, come to $60.00 plus the freight, but we are not prepared to state the cost of the freighting. This boiler was repaired last fall but not completely, and it seems that it will be necessary to change all the flues.

May I have your authority immediately as the boiler will be brought in on May 18th and we are trying to arrange with the Northwestern Iron Works to repair it immediately.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Dear Sir:

Re: Lighting Plants

Kindly refer to yours of June 19th on the subject of lighting plants, one of which we have received at our shops.

On dismantling this engine we found the cylinder badly worn and the valves in bad shape, this apparently due to the fact that water had been leaking into the cylinder head.

It would appear that if the work as detailed below is carried out, this engine would give a number of years of useful life but as no doubt you will understand we have not had an opportunity to check the generator as this would not be possible until the engine has been reconditioned but its condition looks good.

We would propose to re bore the cylinder, supply and fit a new piston complete with rings and wrist pin, reface cylinder head which is now badly pitted, supply two new valves and machine valve seats, re-assemble and test. We estimate this would cost the sum of $214.00, f.o.b. our warehouse.

We have a promise from a foundry on the new piston which would enable us to finish the job in about three weeks.
Awaiting the favour of your instructions,

Yours very truly,

B.C. EQUIPMENT COMPANY LTD.

WJ Roach

extractor to us for this change-over and it would mean chang-
ing all the wiring, motor, pulleys and motor bracket. We
would have to know the alternating current which you are now
getting in this institution, whether it is 60 cycle or 25
and whether the voltage is 550 or 220. This would have to be
3 phase.

With regard to the voltage you state in your letter
that this motor would be 115 AC which they require. This is
not a usual current unless it is that you are going to operate
on single phase, and if so it would take us approximately six
to seven months to get a motor of this type.

Please advise us by return giving this information.

With reference to your wire of Monday last regarding additional wiring at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I have gone into this matter and find that the extractor recently rebuilt for an A.C. (previously D.C.) is equipped with a three phase motor and the power line which runs into the school from the transmission line in, is equipped to run single phase motors.

As the present installation is for a single phase wiring, it will require extending two wires from the high power line to the school and adding transformers with possible erection of a substation. This will cost approximately $1000.00 and for changing the wire within the school, including material, will cost approximately $225.00.

This seems to be a very large expense for changing over one piece of machinery.

I would suggest that you get in touch with the Beaver Laundry Co. who have just recently overhauled and converted this piece of machinery over from D.C. to A.C., to find out if there is no other way this can be equipped to be run by a single phase motor.

The spinner is badly needed at the school and if you could advise me what to do, as soon as possible, it would be very much appreciated.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Edgar:

You will recall that a great deal of correspondence has taken place with regard to the extractor for the Muscowequan Residential School. In order to wire it for the three phase, the labor and material would cost approximately $1200.00. I imagine that it would be less expensive to have the motor changed to a 220 volt A.C. single phase, 60 cycle. CANADA
Theft of Harness (386) from Muscowequan Indian Reserve
Lastock district, Saskatchewan.

(PUBLIC ARCHIVE DETACHMENT CASE)

17-6-46

1. Adverting to the above, confidential information having been received at this Detachment to the effect that one Andrew ALBERT, a treaty Indian of Muscowequan Indian Reserve had been observed with a team which was harnessed similar to that which was missing from the above mentioned school.

2. Pursuant to the above, the writer patrolled via Prov/Car Road Codes 1849 to the Touchwood, Lastock, and Bunkend districts and investigated in the above regard. Andrew ALBERT was located in the Lastock district when it was ascertained that he had attended a wedding on the Muscowequan Reserve on Tuesday June 11th, and that wishing to make a good showing he had painted the harness of his horses a bright yellow and had borrowed a set of harness from McKenzie BLUE-EYES of the Poorman Reserve and had been driven to the wedding in his buggy. It was ascertained that part of the harness was at present with his people who were working in the Bunkend district and the patrol continued to that point where upon arrival at the Indian camp the harness at that point was checked over by an employee of the Muscowequan Indian School, who was familiar with the harness and who had during the winter months repaired same; however, none of the harnesses at this point was found to be that missing from the above mentioned school and the patrol returned to Lastock.

3. Upon arrival at Lastock, Sask., the writer remained at that point to attend the Inquest held by Judge HAJDUK against Death of, Lastock, Sask., and Sgt. J. P. DOUGLAS continued the patrol to the Poorman Indian Reserve to check the Harness of McKenzie BLUE-EYES, upon arrival at the Poorman Reserve, a further check revealed that the harness in possession of BLUE-EYES was not new and not the missing harness. It was further ascertained that BLUE-EYES had purchased this set of Harness in 1945 through the Dept. of Indian Affairs and he was therefore ruled out as a suspect.

4. No further information being forthcoming at this point Capt. Douglas returned to Lastock and contacted the writer, and the patrol returned to Punichy, arriving at 12.30 P.M.

5. This subject will receive further attention the result of which will be the subject of a report to meet the marginally noted diary date.

GABRIEL FORBARD,
DEPENSE SHOWN ON P.93.
(T.H. Playford) 12040
I/c Punichy Detachment.

J.P.B.Ostrander Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

With reference to your letter #906-312-11 ARC, dated June 14th, 1947 I beg to report on fire protection for the Macowegan Indian Residential School in accordance with report of Mr. F.W.Laker, Fire Inspector, and am enclosing herewith requisitions in accordance with his recommendations and also a requisition for 24 Pyrene fire extinguishers which I feel should be placed throughout the building, at least eight on each floor.

The water for this school is taken as you know, from a well and with electric pumps. At times we have trouble with these and if a fire occurred during one of these periods, or the electricity happened to be off, there would be nothing to stop a small blaze from spreading and burning the school.

The Principal feels that the buildings are fire proof, which they are, but we all know that fires can start in buildings of this kind in the furniture, bedding etc., and do an awful lot of damage.

Since Mr. Laker's report the Acting Principal, the Reverend Fr. Robidoux has started fire drill weekly and as soon as these requisitions are approved, I will have the changes made as requested.

The children will be home for the holidays on the 1st July so there will be no-one in the building at that date, until September.

R.S.Davis,

Ottawa, August 29th, 1947.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

We have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to the previous request of the principal of the Muscowequan Residential School for the Department to supply a new stoker.

You forwarded a requisition for this dated July 12th and the suggestion at that time was to purchase a No. 350 Vulcan Stoker at a cost of $1,150.

About the same date that your requisition reached this office, Father DeVarennes visited the Department and the question of the stoker was discussed with him by several of our officials. In addition, Mr. Doucet accompanied Father DeVarennes to the Fairbanks Morse Company where it was found that a suitable stoker could be secured for much less than $1,150.

We took no further action in the matter at the time as Mr. Phelan and Mr. Doucet both definitely understood from Father DeVarennes that on his return West he would give the matter further consideration and submit another requisition through your office. Since that time we have not heard further from him.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Madam:

In reply to your letter re the Single phase Motor for your Extractor, we have contacted the Century Electric Company by wire and by letter and have received a promise of shipment from St. Louis for the week of November 10th, 1947. This means that we should be able to ship your motor and starter before the end of November. We are truly disappointed at the long delay in getting delivery and would like to assure you that we have done everything possible with letters, wires and phone calls and have received promises which have not been kept due to inability to secure delivery of materials.

We definitely realize the seriousness of your position and will do everything we can to try and get this equipment shipped in November.

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

This is a personal letter to you, Mr. Phelan and not intended for filing.

Do you know that for over two years now we are waiting for the single phase motor for the Extractor in our Laundry? The Beaver Laundry who has the matter in hand has sent us a motor over a year ago but not the proper one. Ever since, we get letters such as the one I include here, but no motor.

No one seems to realize what the lack of an Extractor for washings such as ours can mean to those in charge of this work!

It is really unfair to let things go this way.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6319, file 657-5, part 7)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
way any longer and I told the Principal yesterday that I was writing to you and to the Beaver Co. this morning and in fifteen days' time if our Motor has not arrived, he will get me one through any Company and send the bill to the Department. — What do you think of these arrangements?

May be, you believe that being hard up for the washing we do not change the children's clothing as we should! —

We now have hundred and fifty-one children in the house and we wash an average of 3,297 pieces of clothes a week not counting dish towels etc etc....

Having only a small Tumbler for the drying how do you think we manage with all those clothes half wrung in a hand wringer running on a big pulley and so dangerous we can't trust a girl around it? Well, besides looking after the washing business I feel that wringer without the girls help getting awfully wet every time.

To dry the clothes we have to spread them all over the house on radiators, beds, chairs, tables etc making a mess of the whole place and
notice this is a very tiresome work.

Would you like to know that on the washing business at Lestock we have killed three of our young sisters? One died shortly after she left the school and the two others are dragging in the infirmaries after months at the hospital and even at the San and having spent thousands of dollars for operations, X-Rays and hospital bills.

Now, since three years I have taken the job as mine, finding it too hard to give it to any of my sisters. Though very healthy a few years ago, I see myself condemned by the Doctor to nothing but very easy work for a ruined heart and sore throat.

I can't give it away before I see the Laundry properly equipped with an Extractor and a Dryer. For the last item mentioned you will receive a requisition in due form very soon. I believe we will also have to ask for a new washing machine as the one we use was a second-hand one from the Lebret School and is now so old it can break apart anytime.

It wouldn't be wise to wait any longer for without the machine we couldn't wash at all...
Father Clourde on his last visit seemed to realize the Laundry situation but I guess he forgot all about it on his way back to Ottawa.

Now Mr Phelan, I tell you all these things to make you understand what makes our life so hard sometimes in our schools and I believe that if you understand, you will be glad to help us.

We do so much extra work for the sole sake of the children that we like to feel that those in charge are happy to do the same.

May I hope in real help from you Mr Phelan in my Motor problem and may I also count on you to back my requisition for a dryer and washing machine as well as for a kitchen range, ours being completely ruined and creating a three times a day problem?

With my personal thanks and wishes accept those of my twelve sisters who are all happy at their work with your little Indian.

Gratefully yours,

Sister Mary Arthur,
Superior.

Re: Report of Inspection - Muscowequan School by your Dietitian

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Your dietitian on the occasion of her visit to the above school, on October 22 to 25, 1947, recommended the installation of the following equipment in the school kitchen:

1. Replacement of old and unsatisfactory cook stove.
2. Proper pot washing unit in kitchen.
3. Proper dishwashing facilities in dishwashing room.
4. Potato peeler.
5. Electric mixer.
6. Replacement and additions of necessary cooking utensils
7. Covering of floor in diningroom.
8. Suitable water tank (size and structure) to provide sufficient hot water and to endure the very hard water.

She adds that serious consideration should be given to a water softener system.

Hoping that you will be able to give the above your early attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Dear Father Flourde:

We are in receipt of your letter of January 29th with reference to the equipment which the dietitian recommended be supplied to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, the list included in your letter includes equipment that we have not been supplying to residential schools.

At the present time funds are not available. However, we will be prepared to reconsider your request after April 1st but I am not in a position at the present time to give any definite promise that the articles will be supplied.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.O. Flourde, O.M.I.,

Laurier Avenue East,

Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, file G-11 R.C. (121) we regret that owing to lack of funds we cannot give consideration to the purchase of equipment and materials requested by the principal of the Museowequan Indian Residential School.

Bernard F. Neary

Feb. 25th 148

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

After waiting two long months to thank you for my motor I have nothing but bad news again today. The motor sent on December the 30th by the Beaver Co was too weak and had to be sent back. It was found in perfect order and sent back again with a bill of $27.18 for looking it up but it still doesn't work.

To-day the Company wired asking for the whole thing, extractor and motor.

All this business has been made by wire except the "transportation" that took almost three months.

Here comes my part. I just can't go any further like this, my second hand small
winger sent by the Department three years ago being completely ruined and another one, put on a pulley by Father, also finished, I just have to keep on washing till my extractor comes back and that will be when??

What would be the best for me is a small electric washer with attached wringer that I could use even after I get my extractor. It would save time and soft water, so hard to get here, giving small batches of clothes the chance to be washed apart.

It would be very handy right now with the epidemic of jaundice we have in the house, and so many bed clothes to disinfect and wash away from the rest.

After almost three long years of hard work and patient waiting I feel assured the Department can't refuse me this favor and help—and I count on you Mr Phelan, to be my intercessor.

If it's just the question of finding a washer that bothers you, give permission to Father Principal to get me one and I'll have it for my next washing day.

I'm lucky my high pressure steam boiler is
in his hands for repairs right now instead of in a slow Company's like Beaver! Too bad the extractor was not left in his hands too, I would have had it years ago! and with big saving to the Department.

If he were not so short of money he would buy me a machine and wringer right away but at the present time it wouldn't be fair to ask him for that.

He is making so many extra expenses and working so hard all the time to make our work easier that we feel sorry for him. Your Muscowequan School is in capable and devoted hands and you may be sure that all you do for its sake is greatly appreciated.

Trusting in God's help and yours

I am your truly,

Sr Mary Arthur
March 1st, 1948

The motor on the extractor at the Muscowequan Residential School which was originally purchased from the Beaver Washing Machine Co., burned out approximately three years ago. We returned the extractor to the Beaver Machine Co., to install a new motor but they installed a three phase motor instead of a one phase motor. Since that time we have been in constant communication with them and they claim that they could only secure the type of motor required in the United States.

Finally, last fall they secured a motor which we considered would be suitable and it was sent to our school. We have just been advised that this motor does not operate the machine properly and as a consequence, the extractor will again have to be sent to Toronto. In the meantime, the school is left without adequate washing facilities. This school has an authorized pupilage of 103. It is essential that some washing facilities should be made available as it may take several months before the extractor is returned to the school.

March 1st, 1948.

Dear Father Robidoux:

This morning I received a letter from Sister Mary Arthur and am extremely sorry to learn that the motor recently forwarded by the Beaver Laundry Company is not yet satisfactory.

Evidently the only course to take is to return the extractor to the Company in order that they may install a proper motor on it.

Mr. Doucet expects to be in Toronto within the next week or ten days and will interview the Company again regarding the matter. In the meantime, arrangements have been made to secure a Connor Thermo Monel Washer and this is going forward to you immediately and I hope it will reach you in the near future and will be of assistance to you temporarily until your own washer is returned.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Principal,

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, March 19, 1948.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrender, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Regina, Saskatchewan.

We received your telegram of March 16th with reference to the beds supplied for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. The beds were requested on your requisition of November 12, 1947 and later purchase order 24963 was issued.

We cannot understand why the company should forward hospital beds to you as we ordered the usual institutional beds.

For your information I enclose specifications of the beds and springs which we ordered and if they are not in accordance with these specifications, you may return them to the company. At the same time you should advise us so that we can communicate with the Globe Bedding Company and arrange to have the proper beds and springs delivered.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

c/o to R.S.Davis.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

On November 13, 1947, I forwarded a requisition for supplies for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in which was included 25 beds and mattresses.

On or about December 20, 1947, 25 beds size 2ft 6" by 5 ft 6" and mattresses for same were received at the school and vouchered for by my voucher #1080 dated December 20, 1947.

The order number shown on the account from the Globe Bedding Company, Winnipeg, Man., was #24068.

Another shipment of 25 beds and mattresses from the Elebe Bedding Company Ltd Winnipeg, Man., has been received at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School as enclosed accounts. As you will see, these beds are 3 ft wide and too large for children, and in any case are not required by the school. These appear to have been ordered by Purchasing order #24963.

The beds appear to be for an older person. Is it possible these have been ordered for some other place and sent to the school by mistake.

Please advise me by wire what you would like done with these as I am still holding them at the station.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, March 23, 1948.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 20th instant with reference to the beds and mattresses which recently arrived at Lestock, Sask. When we received the message from Mr. Ostrander on March 16th we understood that the point at issue was that hospital beds had been supplied instead of institutional beds. No doubt you have received by this time the copy of our letter to Mr. Ostrander dated March 19th.

On receipt of your letter of March 20th I reviewed our file and find on the request of the principal we ordered 25 beds and 25 mattresses in October and as you state, these reached the school and the account covering their cost has been paid. When we received your letter of November 13th, we overlooked the fact that we had already ordered beds and mattresses and consequently another order was placed for them.

Please consult with Mr. Ostrander and ascertain if there is any other residential school that requires beds and mattresses and if so, you may ship them to them. The account may be certified and returned so that payment can be made from our appropriation.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

With reference to my Voucher #419 in favor of General Steel Wares, Limited Winnipeg, Man., for a Chef Jr range for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I would state that the account for this was received on April 24th last, but without the receipted freight bill attached.

A letter was written to General Steel Wares asking for this, under date of April 24, but to date has not been answered.

The Reverend Fr. Robidoux, Principal of the Muscowequan School, phoned the office this afternoon stating he had received a wire from Mr. Neary, requesting that the account be forwarded by airmail at once. The range had been received at the school this afternoon.

As this appears to be urgent, I am forwarding voucher without the receipted freight bill for $32.50 and will send this on when received here.

With reference to Department letter 121-5-5 (El) dated April 22, 1948, I have taken up the matter of the expenditure of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School with the Principal, as requested, and he has reduced the amount of paint required as he will not do some of the work this year.

I am enclosing herewith amended requisition for the paint. Fr. Robidoux has taken his prices for this from Ashdown's catalogue. However, if this was ordered from Sherwin-Williams Paint Company, Winnipeg, it would reduce the cost considerably as they allow us manufacturer's price, which is below the wholesale price.

With reference to the dryer. I am enclosing herewith a drawing of the dryer. A lot of work has been done already by the Father on this as it is necessary to have some place to dry the cloths. These were hanging all over the engine room, halls and everything else. When completed I consider it will cost quite a bit more than shown on the requisition as Fr. I would recommend that if possible this expenditure be approved.

R.B. Davis,
Superintendent.

portable machine. Electric current is supplied to the motor from an electric light socket through a cord as shown in Fig. 210. Any desired speed, up to 1000 stitches a minute, may be obtained by varying the pressure of the foot on the lever of the controller, which is placed on the floor next to the treadle, as shown in Fig. 212, or by the pressure of the knee lever shown in Figs. 216 and 219.

When running at full speed the motor consumes about the same current as a 50 watt electric lamp. As most sewing is done intermittently and at various speeds according to the nature of the work, the average cost of operation is about one cent for four hours of sewing.

All working parts of this motor are entirely enclosed and absolutely safe. The wiring is the same as on other electric appliances such as fans, toasters, irons, etc., and may be handled in the same manner.

Electric Lights for Sewing Machines

The problem of proper illumination for sewing has been solved by the use of a small electric lamp attached to the machine and arranged to throw the rays of light on the bed of the machine without glaring into the eyes of the operator. Fig. 211 shows this ingenious device, known as the "Singerlight," attached to the back of the arm and connected by a short cord to the cord supplying electricity to the motor. When
the machine has no motor attached, a longer cord is furnished for the light. The lamp consumes only 15 watts, making the cost of electricity negligible. The amount of light is just right for either light or dark goods and the location of the lamp is such as not to interfere with the free passage of goods under the arm, even on bulky work.

With such a light, sewing may be done without eye strain in any part of the home at any time. It is unnecessary to move the machine near a window to get good light or to wait for a bright day to do your sewing. Artificial illumination usually found in homes is generally unsatisfactory for sewing, being insufficient or casting shadows on the work. The practice of placing oil, gas or electric lights on the leaf of the machine or a nearby table is dangerous, as they are so easily knocked off.

**Various Types of Electric Sewing Machines**

Electric sewing machines are of three principal types: treadle machines with a motor attached, portable machines and cabinet table machines.

The older form of electric sewing machine is the ordinary treadle machine to which a motor has been added, as shown in Fig. 212. The motor is attached with a single screw to the seat on the arm below the balance wheel, the regular belt removed, the motor belt put on its place, the motor cord screwed into an electric light socket, the foot control box connected to the motor cord and the treadle machine has become an electric. The whole process takes only a few minutes and can be done by anyone without electrical or mechanical skill. Should it ever become necessary to revert back to treadle operation, this can be done by removing the motor belt and putting on the belt running from the band.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I thank you for giving your kind attention to my previous letter, and will try to give a satisfactory answer to your favour of the 5th instant.

I believe it is necessary to attach Singerlights to the sewing machines to give proper illumination to each operator, especially during the long winter months, the regular sewing hour being from 5 to 6 p.m.; our pupils being now allowed to attend class all day, giving them, thus, the opportunity to achieve their school grades.

It is not that our sewing room is not conveniently illuminated; but, the bulbs suspended at 18" from the ceiling that is 5 ft. from the sewing machines, don't give enough light to the students; and, if they were lowered their rays would glare in the eyes of the operators, which, of course, would not be of any help.

I've always wondered myself why the sewing instructors of our Indian Schools have never thought of asking the Department for those wonderful singerlights so justly appreciated in all sewing circles and obtainable as per illustration herein enclosed - at the reasonable cost of $2.50 from any of the Singer shops. And, since I'm now appointed to teach sewing to the Indian girls, I think it fair to try to have my pupils share the benefit of the singerlights.

We have actually 12 sewing machines all in fairly good condition on which 36 of our older girls take sewing lessons.

We would be deeply grateful to you, dear Mr. Phelan, if you could possibly supply our School with a good electric Darning machine; we have been unsuccessfully asking for one since several years ago; we understand that during the war these machines were unavailable, but, if you could now be favoured with one, it would help so much of the pupils to get rid sooner of the tedious chore of the mending and enable them to learn many pleasant things so useful for their future home life.

Please excuse me, dear Mr. Phelan, for the length of this letter, but I thought these details might help to convince you that my request for the "singerlights" was not, after all, quite so extravagant as it may have seemed at first.

Very sincerely yours,

Memorandum

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School #657, Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of April 12th which bears your marginal notation of the 13th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

A study of the original plans reveals that the building was erected in 1930-1931 and that the original heating system was designed for two pipe low pressure steam with two 5000 square foot capacity return tubular low pressure steam steel heating boilers. The layout of piping according to the plans, is along conventional lines and the accessories including steam traps, valves, etcetera, are of a type in general use at the time the work was installed. No return pump was called for. Condensation is returned to the boilers through a combination boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

If this assembly is still in use, it can be reasonably assumed that the interior mechanism would not be in good operating condition after so many years of service as there is a tendency for rust and scale to develop.

Mr. MacKay's memorandum contains a suggestion to convert this system to a vacuum return type as a means of improving the performance of the heating system.

In a building which has been up for nineteen years, this operation would involve work of a major character and it is questionable at this time whether such a changeover would be warranted. In order to convert to a vacuum return system, not only is a vacuum pump required but every section of piping and all fittings including valves, traps, etcetera, must be thoroughly checked for minute air and steam leaks. It is possible that all the radiator traps would have to be replaced, and it is a certainty that new traps would have to be provided at the ends of all steam mains.

We are writing to Mr. Perrie requesting him to carry out an inspection based on a questionnaire prepared by this Division. It is expected that following receipt of this survey, we will be able to make recommendations designed to improve the heating system without the necessity of changing over to a vacuum design.

When Mr. Perrie's data is received and analysed you will be further advised.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

A basket of glasses may be alternated with a basket of greasy dishes and yet they will come out sparkling clean. Hot water should be held at not less than 140 degrees for washing. Temperature drop of only 30 degrees occurs in its passage to the wash reservoir and through the machine's circulation system, so that no other thermal control is needed. Reverend Father O. Robidoux, Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, has requested a mixer, an electric potato peeler, and an electric dishwasher.

All moving parts are machined and the Block is provided with Steel Guides to ensure that it engages truly with the Cutting Knives.

I presume our Branch will have received a copy of the report of Mr. W.W. Perrie, Supervising Engineer, on his inspection of the roofs of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, dated June 23rd, 1949, his file I A 556-6.

Re Roof Repairs, Muscowequan Residential School, Touchwood Agency, Saskatchewan.

We are in receipt of a report dated June 23, 1949, from Mr. W.W. Perrie, Supervising Engineer at our Regina office. He states Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor, Indian Affairs, Saskatchewan, requested an inspection of the roof of the above school, which was reported to be leaking badly.

The first report of roof leakage appears to be on September 24, 1936, when the building had been erected for some eight years. The roof was reported to be in bad condition and at that time, it was recommended to be relaid.

The roof of the main building was relaid in 1942 at a cost of $1,725.00. It now appears that the roofs of the entire establishment are leaking, causing distress to occupants, and damage to ceilings, partitions and interior walls. The main roof seems to be holding up with the exception of flashings around drains, ventilators and parapet walls.

The report contains no reference to any structural defects in the roof construction, undue settlement or shrinkage, so it must be assumed that workmanship and economical use of flashing and roofing materials are at fault. We have checked the original plans for structural strength, and if installed as shown, no fault can be found with the structural steel design, which plans indicate as web steel joists and steel beams.

The essentials of the report show that certain roofs must be entirely relaid, others will be satisfactory with portions of roof relaid, while considerable repairs to the flashing is required. The estimated cost of the work is $1,250.00 plus contingencies $125.00, and engineering services and inspection of $350.00, a total of $1,725.00. Mr. Perrie advises that the work should be done immediately as the leaking from roof areas was very bad during recent heavy rains.

We attach a copy of Mr. W.W. Perrie's report and white print showing itemized roof areas for the information of Indian Affairs Branch.

Further to our memorandum of April 21st with reference to the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of a report from Mr. Perrie dated July 6th covering his inspection trip to this school. Mr. Perrie's report may be summed up as follows.

From his observations together with advice received from the Principal and the operating engineer, the heating system appears to be fundamentally sound in general. It is stated that the Sewing Room and Girls' Classroom on the ground floor and the Boys' Dormitory on the first floor are difficult to heat in the cold weather. It is the unanimous opinion of Mr. Perrie, the Principal and the operating engineer that this difficulty is not due to faulty traps. Mr. Perrie reports that the condensation from these areas does not return freely to the boiler return trap. He also states that the "injector" which we take to be the boiler return trap does not function satisfactorily. It was also noted that the return lines in certain sections of the building showed signs of sagging which would account in some measure for the retarded circulation. The report states that the pipe gradients are generally satisfactory as far as can be observed. We are advised that the high pressure boiler which serves several items of laundry equipment has been condemned by the Provincial Boiler Inspector.

After a careful study of Mr. Perrie's report together with a thorough examination of the original heating plans, we can offer the following comment and recommendations:

There is no reason to doubt that the heating system was installed in accordance with the original plans. These plans are well laid out in general and with one or two minor exceptions, can be considered to contain the elements of good design. Upon calculating the heat loss in the Girls' Sewing Room, Boys' Classroom and Boys' Dormitory it was found that additional radiation will be required to bring these rooms up to 70 degrees F. against the recognized 35 degrees F. below zero outside base temperature. It will also be necessary to check the gradient of all the return mains and to re-grade some where necessary down in the direction of flow 1/4" in 10'-0". All run outs from steam and return mains to ground floor radiators and risers must also be checked for proper gradient. These lines should be graded back to mains 1/4" per foot.

The boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly can be considered practically useless and should be replaced by a relatively inexpensive horizontal condensation return pump. This will entail some minor piping revisions at the boilers.

A new vertical high pressure boiler is needed for the laundry services. In conclusion it is therefore recommended, on the strength of Mr. Perrie's report together with data obtained from the original plans, that the following operations be carried out in order to bring the heating system up to a reasonable standard.

(a) Install an additional 40 square feet E.D.R. in the Sewing Room.

(b) Install an additional 30 square feet E.D.R. in the Girls' Classroom.

(c) Install an additional 60 square feet E.D.R. in the Boys' Dormitory.

(d) Check return mains throughout and re-grade where necessary by means of shortening some connections, adjusting hangers, etcetera. Check and adjust grade of all run outs and spring pieces to ground floor radiator connections and to risers.

(e) Install new horizontal condensation pump and connect to boilers using the Hartford loop arrangement.

(f) Provide new 10 H.P. high pressure vertical steel boiler for laundry services.

Until a layout can be made it will not be possible to provide an accurate estimate of the cost of the above work, but it is felt that the sum of $3,000.00 will be required.

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:

(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and

(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:

(a) the safety valve is set to relieving at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;

(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;

(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I just received your letter of the 12th inst (File No. 121 - 5 - IO) regarding the discharge of Dan Kennedy's son.

I would object to Gordon's discharge, for the false reasons Mr. Kennedy has given and the discredit he is throwing upon our School.

When this boy came to our School in Oct. 1932, he could not follow our 3rd Grade, so he had to pass a year and a half in the same class, then he was promoted to the 4th, then to the 5th, where he now stands, contrary to what Mr. Kennedy wrote.

Now regarding their remark about the "over emphasis Religious Instruction we are giving here, to the detriment of Academic Instruction". This is absolutely false. The boys of Grades 4 and 5 are together for religious Instruction and they receive 1/2 hour a day of Religious Instruction. Should the Rel. Inst. be to the detriment of Academic Inst., as Mr. Kennedy said, we would not have been 2nd, for the province of Sask., for the prizes of Class-Work won at the Regina Exhibition this Summer. Our School won 70 prizes for Class Work only. Mr. Murison and Mr. Moir - our School Inspector - could tell you what they think regarding the good standing of our School.

The only reason, Mr. Kennedy has is to distinguish himself from the others and to keep the boy at home but my opinion is that he should have said it frankly without throwing any discredit upon our School. I would like very much to have the boy return until he'll be 16, then he would be prepared for his admission to High School.

Thanking you very much for your kind attention, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

I am a member of the Muscowequon Indian Band residing on Muscowequon Indian Reserve No. 85; I have two children, a boy and a girl, (Mary Jane age 10 years past) the boy Frank is 13 years old.

My girl has been attending the Muscowequon Indian Mission at Lestock now for four years, and is still unable to recite the A, B, C alphabet, the boy owing to sickness has not attended so long, but he is very backward for the time he has been in school, I have decided that I am going to take my children out of the Muscowequon Indian Mission School, and place them in a public school and pay for their education in the public school.

I do therefore most respectfully request that I be granted a Permit to take my children from the Muscowequon Indian Mission School, and place them in the public school on the south of the reserve[to-wit:]Virag School which is willing to take my children and educate them along with the white children. I am verily informed that to comply with the Education Act, that so long as my children are receiving the proper education as prescribed by the Saskatchewan School Act, that this ten mile grant at any place set apart for the education of pupils. Therefore it is my intention to discontinue to send my children to the Muscowequon Indian Mission School, and to send them to the Virag School District, where I verily believe that they will obtain better education than they have been getting at the Mission. For your information I myself did attend at this same Mission School when I was a boy for twelve long years, and can scarcely read a newspaper now, I do not wish to go into this matter, but, I am not satisfied with the education my children are getting, there: I respectfully beg for a permit to avoid further trouble with the school principal with regard to the attendance of my children at the said school.

Your reply will be earnestly awaited.

Yours truly

J. B. Desjarlais
Ottawa, September 17, 1936.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of a letter from J. B. Desjarlais, in which he applies for the discharge of his two children from the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. Please inform Desjarlais that the Department is not prepared to grant the discharge of these children at the present time and that they must remain in the Muscowequan School.

In his letter, Desjarlais complains that his children are not making satisfactory progress in their studies. The Department does not place much reliance in this statement, as the report of Inspector R. C. Moir, who inspected the school on January 9th, last, read in part as follows:

"The work in all three classrooms shows continued expansion. The problem of oral language is being attacked on many sides. Written language and drawing continue to be the 'show' work of the school. I found need of systematic drill in the mechanics of arithmetic, a need which has already been felt by the teachers and is being met. Among the junior pupils I noted a freedom and happiness, a spontaneity which I thought desirable."

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland.
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

Ottawa, November 6, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of October 22, enclosing letters received from Indian Agent Waddy and the Principal of the Muscovequian Indian Residential School, with reference to the admission of the children of Mr. Charles Folstrom.

In 1931 we received request for the admission of these children to an Indian residential school. Information supplied at that time indicated that Folstrom is an American Indian, who, previous to 1931, had resided for about twelve years near Lestock, Saskatchewan.

At that time Mr. Waddy was informed that the Department did not consider these children our wards and therefore we were not prepared to consider admitting them to any Indian residential school. After carefully considering the present application, I can see no reason for changing the decision made in 1931.

From the information we have received, I am inclined to feel that Folstrom is entitled to send his children to a "white" school. If he has lived in the Province for some 15 years he is entitled to the same privileges in regard to education as to any other resident.

Yours truly,

2. No-one by the names above mentioned was known to be on the reserve, but an Indian or half-breed living near the reserve by the name of Magnus COURTOIS, was interviewed who had a brother attending Leestock school by the name of Alex COURTOIS, which is possibly the person referred to as missing. This boy's father resides on the Reserve at Kamsack, Sask., by the name of Joe COURTOIS. There are no Indians on Valley River Reserve named FLATFOOT, although there are Indians by that name living at the Pine Creek Reserve, not in this detachment area.

3. The Indian overseer from the Valley River Reserve called at this detachment on the evening of 5-11-37, and said that three boys were seen by an Indian getting on a box car, on a train (freight) going east on the afternoon of 4-11-37, from Dauphin, on the Indian reservation.

4. There is a possibility that the boys seen are the ones missing from Leestock school, and in which case they may be going to the Pine Creek reserve, the overseer says that if they were on Valley River Reserve he would have heard about it from some of the Indians.

MANITOBA NOV 8th 1937.

Alex. CONTIS et al., Lestock, Sask.
Muscowequan Indian Residential School.
Running away from:
"Gladstone Detachment Case"

1. Reference to the above matter. On the 21st ultimo this office was notified by Cpl. Alcock, i/o Gladstone Detachment to the effect that three boys had run away from the Lestock Indian School, and it was alleged that they might be in the Westbourne district and on account of other Police Duties in the Gladstone Detachment requiring attention, a request was made that the investigation be made by this Detachment which was in order with M.C.O. this Detachment. The three boys described as follows: Telegram received from Mr. J. Jeannette Lestock and received by J. White, Indian Agent this point.

Alex. CONTIS: 15 Years, Tall and Thin, from Longplains Reserve, wearing: Overalls, Sweater, Smock, Light Blue cap- Leather Boots.
Augustin Flatfoot: 14 Years, Short from Flatfoot Reserve transferred from Lebret School, wearing Overalls-Black Cap- Leather windbreaker & boots.
Albert McGregor: 11 Years, 4' 10" from Lestock wearing Overalls- Gray Cap-Sweater and Smock-Rubber boots.

On the 11-11 and acting on instructions received from the M.C.O., this Detachment the writer patrolled to the Westbourne district per P.C. #1666 where enquiries were made among the local Indians with respect to the boys above mentioned but in this connection replies were in the negative no boys as described having been seen by any of the Indians interviewed. These inquiries were instructed to notify this or Gladstone Detachments by telephone should the boys show up. In view of the fact that the Indian families at this time are very few in the Westbourne district, the majority having left for their respective reserves, it is doubtful if the boys would show up in Westbourne, not being known by the Indians still remaining.

On the 3rd instant while in the Westbourne district on other duties further enquiries were made by Cpl. Alcock with negative results. This information was given to the Indian Agent who stated that he was in receipt of further information to the effect that these boys may have gone to Shortdale, Man., and he has communicated direct with Inspector i/o Dauphin S/Div., with a request for a check at that point.

As no trace of these boys could be found in this district and it is possible they are in the Dauphin S/Div area this file is being considered as:

The G.C. Brandon S/Div
R.C.M.P. Brandon, Man.

23.10.37.

1. While in Lestock on this date on other police
duties I was met by the Rev.Father Jeanotte- Principal
of the Mescowegan Indian Residential School- Lestock,
Sask., who advised me that six of the Indian school boys
of the said school had run away, and it had been uncertain-
ed that the boys had boarded a freight train and gone East.
As a result Father Jeanotte telephoned direct to the RCMP,
at Melville for a look out to be kept for the boys and
detained if located. One of the boys, Hilliard Borm was duly
located at Melville and held, I was in turn notified and
advised Father Jeanotte who went for the boy and returned
him from Melville back to the school (please refer to rept.
of Capt.Shank-Melville-dated Oct.26th/37. Reg:Hilliard worm-
Runaway Indian boy- Lestock,Sask.)

2. A few days later I was further advised by Father
Jeanotte that two of the other boys (Salter Wolf- and
Alex. Asdechonah) had also been returned to the school, and
at this time I was advised by Father Jeanotte that the other
missing boys had gone to the Reserves in the district of
Portage la Prairie- and that as he was going to that point,
he would endeavour to locate and bring the missing boys
back with him. Father Jeanotte made his visit to the Portage
la Prairie area while there reported the location of the boys to the
Indian Agent who in turn notified the local RCMP, and
from report received I was surprised to learn that the
boys had not been located. Father Jeanotte failed to advise
me on his return as to whether he succeeded in locating the
boys, as I expected that he would do, and as a result I was
of the impression that the boys had been brought back by
him.

22.11.37.

Mr Philip Phelan,

OTTAWA.

My dear Mr Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Anicinapeau school re. the desertion of a group of boys from his school last September. The Principal informs me that the older boys of the school are given work with pay on the school farm every fall. This year, owing to the crop failure, there was no work for them. Several enquiries from the adjoining reserve having heard that the crops in Manitoba were very good and that there was work for harvesters, induced the older boys of the school to join them in a proposed journey to Manitoba. Of course, this appealed very much to the older boys of the school and they readily joined the party. Unfortunately, they found very little work and, in some cases, were not even paid for the few days that they did work.

The escape of these boys was made very easy owing to the fact that the regular disciplinarian, Mr Schmidt, was at the time in the hospital. The boys are now all back in school and seem to be the wiser for the hardships and sufferings endured during their absence from school.

My intention, in giving you the above explanation, is to dispel the impression that the authorities at Anicinapeau might have been laxed in enforcing discipline or that the general conditions of the school were so poor as to prompt these boys to run away.

Yours very truly,

At 9 p.m., of the 6th inst., phone call was received from Father Jeanette, principal of above mentioned residential school, who reported that Edgar MICKLE, aged 14 years, wearing blue woolen sweater and a mackinaw coat, with blue overalls and cap, had run away from this school on this same date. Edgar MICKLE is short and stout, and the principal of the school thought he may try to get to Kenora, Ont., and therefore requested that all trains eastbound be checked at this point; and should the exceptionally noted be found, have him held at this detachment and advise Father Jeanette by L.D. telephone.

On receipt of the above phone call, I contacted the Cst. on night patrol of the Town of Melville, and acquainted him with the facts in this case. A close check of all eastbound trains by members of this detachment failed to reveal any trace of the runaway Indian boy.
